page.title: List of worker deaths in United States labor disputes

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
The following '''list of worker deaths in United States labor disputes''' captures known incidents of fatal labor-related violence in U.S. labor history, which began in the colonial era with the [[Timeline of labor issues and events|earliest worker demands]] around 1636 for better working conditions. It does not include killings of enslaved persons. According to a study in 1969, the United States has had the bloodiest and most violent labor history of any industrial nation in the world, and there have been few industries which have been immune.<ref>Philip Taft and Philip Ross, "American Labor Violence: Its Causes, Character, and Outcome," The History of Violence in America: A Report to the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence, ed. Hugh Davis Graham and Ted Robert Gurr, 1969.</ref>
This list is not comprehensive. A number of factors (multi-sided conflicts, physically remote locations, company-controlled locations, exaggerated or biased original reporting, etc.) make some of the death and injury counts uncertain.
==By authorities==
===Law enforcement and companies' militia, armed detectives and guards=== :{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; font-size:87%; border:1; cellpadding:5; cellspacing:0;" !scope="col" data-sort-type="date"|Date !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Industry !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Type of dispute !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Workers killed by authorities !scope="col" class="unsortable" |Notes |---- |August 8, 1850 |Manhattan, NYC, NY | style="text-align: center;"|Garment | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |At least two tailors died as police confronted a street mob of about 300 strikers, mostly German, with clubs.<ref>Chants Democratic: New York City and the Rise of the American Working Class, by Sean Wilentz, 2004, pages 380-381, citing the [[New York Herald]] for August 6 and 7, 1850, and the [[New York Tribune]] for August 5 and 6, 1850</ref> These deaths stand as the "first recorded strike fatalities in U.S. history".<ref>Civil War America, 1850 to 1875, by Richard F. Selcer, 2014, page 88</ref> |---- |July 7, 1851 |Portage, NY | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Two striking workers of the New York and Erie Railroad were shot and killed by police officers. Strikers were dispersed the following morning by the state militia.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=zKkWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA449&lpg=PA449&dq=portage+%22new+york%22+railroad+strike+1851#v=onepage&q=portage%20%22new%20york%22%20railroad%20strike%201851&f=false |title=A History of Livingston County, New York: From Its Earliest Traditions, to Its Part in the War for Our Union: with an Account of the Seneca Nation of Indians, and Biographical Sketches of Earliest Settlers and Prominent Public Men|first=Lockwood Lyon|last=Doty|publisher=Edward L. Doty|year=1876|pages=449–450}}</ref> |--- |May 17, 1871 |Hyde Park section of Scranton, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Coal | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Two strikers, Benjamin Davis and Daniel Jones,<ref>''Scranton Republican'', Saturday, September 30, 1916, page 43, partially visible online at https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/48843322/</ref> were shot and killed by a single bullet fired in Scranton during the 1871 [[Workingmen's Benevolent Association of Schuylkill County|Workingmen's Benevolent Association]] union coal strike. The shot was fired under the command of William W. Scranton.{{dubious| The source says the shot was fired by a non-striking worker, possibly in self-defense.|date=April 2016}} Eight thousand people attended the strikers' funeral.<ref>"Imposing Demonstration at the Two Miners' Funeral." New York Times, May 19, 1871</ref> |---- |July 20, 1877 |Baltimore, MD | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|10 |During the [[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]], first national strike in United States, National Guard regiments were ordered to [[Cumberland, Maryland]], to face strikers. As they marched toward their train in Baltimore, violent street battles between the striking workers and the guardsmen erupted. Troops fired on the crowd, killing 10 and wounding 25.<ref name="scharf">{{Cite book|last=Scharf|first=J. Thomas|title=History of Maryland From the Earliest Period to the Present Day: 1819-1880|publisher=John B. Piet |date=1879|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XnsjAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=bibliogroup:%22History+of+Maryland+from+the+Earliest+Period+to+the+Present+Day%22#v=onepage&q&f=false |location = Baltimore, Maryland|pages=732–42 }}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 21, 1877"|July 21–22, 1877 |Pittsburgh, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|40 |[[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]: As militiamen approached and sought to protect the roundhouse, they bayoneted and fired on rock-throwing strikers, killing 20 people and wounding 29.<ref name="UE">{{cite web |last= |first= |title=The Great Strike of 1877: Remembering a Worker Rebellion|work= |publisher=UE News|date=June 2002|url=http://www.ranknfile-ue.org/uen_1877.html|doi= |accessdate=2008-05-25}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=July 2017}}The next day, the militia mounted an assault on the strikers, shooting their way out of the roundhouse and killing 20 more people. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 21, 1877"|July 21–28, 1877 |East St. Louis, IL and St. Louis, MO | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad, then general | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="18"|up to about 18 |[[1877 St. Louis general strike]] part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877: The first general strike in the United States was ended when 3000 federal troops and 5000 deputized police had killed at least 18 people in skirmishes around the city. |---- |July 23, 1877 |Reading, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|10 |In the [[Reading Railroad massacre]], part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877, a unit of the [[Pennsylvania State Police]] ventured into the Seventh Street Cut (a man-made railway ravine) to address a train disabled by rioters. They were bombarded from above with bricks and stones, harassed, and finally they fired a rifle volley into the crowd at the far end, killing ten.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://explorepahistory.com/hmarker.php?markerId=1-A-1AD|title= Reading Railroad Massacre Historical Marker|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref><ref>Anthracite's Demise and the Post-Coal Economy of Northeastern Pennsylvania, by Thomas Keil, Jacqueline M. Keil, 2014, page 39</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 25, 1877"|July 25–26, 1877 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|30 |[[Battle of the Viaduct]], part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877: Violence erupted between a crowd and police, federal troops, and state militia at the Halsted Street Viaduct. When it ended, 30 were dead.<ref>{{cite book|first=Richard |last=Schneirov|title=Labor and Urban Politics: Class Conflict and the Origins of Modern Liberalism in Chicago, 1864-97|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Urbana and Chicago, Illinois, U.S.|year=1998|pages=75, 95|isbn=978-0252066764| quote=Police violence had taken a terrible toll: approximately thirty were killed − the true number could not be reported since many were buried at night in lime pits south of the city − and another two hundred were wounded. (These figures are estimates based on comparing newspaper accounts and names of casualties.) Not one policeman or militiaman was killed.}}</ref>
|---- |August 1, 1877 |Scranton, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Coal, Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|4 |[[Scranton General Strike]], part of the Great Railroad Strike of 1877: The day after railroad workers conceded and returned to work, angry striking miners clashed with a 38-man posse partly led by [[William Walker Scranton]], general manager of the Lackawanna Iron & Coal Company. When a posse member was shot in the knee, the posse responded by killing or fatally wounding four of the strikers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thomasgenweb.com/hyde_park_history.html|title=Hyde Park History|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref><ref name=scranton>{{cite book|title= New England Families, Genealogical and Memorial: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of Commonwealths and the Founding of a Nation, Volume 4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=NfksAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1841&lpg=PA1841&dq=Worthington+Scranton+mining+1871#v=onepage&q=Worthington%20Scranton%20mining%201871&f=false|page=1841|editor-first=William|editor-last=Cutter|year=1913|accessdate=2015-09-11|publisher=Lewis Historical Publishing Company}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="August 2, 1877"|1877 |Philadelphia, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="21"|20–30 |[[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]: 30–70 injured in addition to those killed<ref name=Ferguson>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9F08RUn2ot8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Emma Goldman: Political Thinking in the Streets| first=Kathy E.|last= Ferguson| publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|location =Lanham, Maryland, USA|date= April 16, 2011|isbn=9781442210486}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="August 4, 1877"|1877 |Buffalo, NY | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|8 |[[Great Railroad Strike of 1877]]: 8 killed<ref name="Ferguson"/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |May 4, 1885 |Lemont, Illinois | style="text-align: center;"|quarry | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|2 |Troops of the Illinois state militia, pitted against "the most desperate and howling mob" of immigrant quarrymen and their women, throwing cobblestones, fired into the crowd. They killed two Polish strikers, Jacob Kugawa and Henry Stiller, and wounded several others with bayonets.<ref>{{cite news|title=The First Blood A Collision Between the Militia and the Strikers at Lemont|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/illinois/bloomington/bloomington-weekly-leader/1885/05-07/page-4?tag=strikers+killed|accessdate=20 April 2016|publisher=Bloomington Illinois Weekly Leader|date=7 May 1885}}</ref> |---- |April 28, 1886 |St. Louis, Missouri | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Striker John Gibbons, fatally shot by a "non-union switchman and private watchman" in St. Louis, was among ten known casualties of the [[Great Southwest railroad strike of 1886]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The official history of the great strike of 1886 on the Southwestern railway system|date=1886|publisher=Missouri Bureau of Labor Statistics|page=113|url=https://archive.org/details/officialhistoryo00miss|accessdate=7 April 2016}}</ref>{{Dubious| The source describes simple self-defense against 3 attackers.|date=April 2016}} |---- |data-sort-type="date"|May 3, 1886 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|Machinery mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|4 |McCormick Harvester strike<ref name=Ferguson/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |May 5, 1886 |Milwaukee, WI | style="text-align: center;"|building trades | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|15 |[[Bay View Massacre]]: As protesters chanted for an 8-hour workday, 250 state militia were ordered to shoot into the crowd as it approached the iron rolling mill at Bay View, leaving 7 dead at the scene, including a 13-year-old boy. The Milwaukee Journal reported that eight more died within 24 hours. |---- |November 5, 1887 |Pattersonville, LA | style="text-align: center;"|Sugar | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="20"|as many as 20 |10,000 sugar workers (90% of whom were black), organized by the [[Knights of Labor]], went on strike. A battalion of national guardsmen supporting a sheriff's posse massacred as many as 20 people in the black village of Pattersonville, [[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Uncivil war: five New Orleans street battles and the rise and fall of radical Reconstruction|first=James Keith|last=Hogue|page=191|publisher=LSU Press|year=2011}}</ref> |---- |November 23, 1887 |Thibodaux, LA | style="text-align: center;"|Sugar | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="37"|37 or more estimated |[[Thibodaux Massacre]]: Louisiana Militia, aided by bands of prominent citizens, shot at least 35 unarmed black sugar workers striking to gain a dollar-per-day wage and lynched two strike leaders. "No credible official count of the victims was ever made; bodies continued to turn up in shallow graves outside of town for weeks to come."<ref>{{cite book|first=Rebecca Jarvis|last=Scott|title=Degrees of Freedom: Louisiana and Cuba after Slavery|publisher=Belknap Press|year=2008|page=85|isbn=978-0674027596}}</ref> |---- |July 6, 1889 |Duluth, Minnesota | style="text-align: center;"|Laborers | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Several days of street riots and strikes by unorganized city laborers climaxed with an hour-long gun battle on Michigan Street with municipal police. Two Finnish strikers, Ed Johnson and Matt Mack, later died of their wounds. Another estimated 30 were wounded, and another young bystander was killed by a stray bullet.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hudelson|first1=Richard|last2=Ross|first2=Carl|title=By the Ore Docks: A Working People's History of Duluth|date=2006|publisher=U of Minnesota Press|page=21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F865CRqof1oC&pg=PA21|accessdate=14 April 2017|isbn=9781452908779}}</ref> |---- |April 3, 1891 |Morewood, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|9 |[[Morewood massacre]]: Miners struck the coke works of industrialist [[Henry Clay Frick]] for higher wages and an 8-hour work day.<ref name="morewood-oldminer">{{cite web|url=http://patheoldminer.rootsweb.ancestry.com/morewood2.html|title=Massacre at Morewood Mine & Coke Works, (Coal Miners Strike of 1891)|accessdate=2008-05-10|last1=Washlaski|first1=Raymond A.|first2=Ryan P.|last2=Washlaski|date=2006-11-12|work=Virtual Museum of Coal Mining in Western Pennsylvania}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://explorepahistory.com/hmarker.php?markerId=1-A-2CB|title=Morewood Massacre [Bituminous Coal] Historical Marker|accessdate=2015-09-12|work=ExplorePAhistory.com|publisher=WITF, Inc.|location=Harrisburg, Pennsylvania}}</ref> As a crowd of about 1000 strikers accompanied by a brass band marched on the company store, deputized members of the 10th Regiment of the National Guard fired several volleys <ref>{{cite book|title=Official Documents, Comprising the Department and Other Reports Made to the Governor, Senate and House of Representatives of Pennsylvania, Volume 4|date=1892|publisher=State of Pennsylvania|page=D - 8}}</ref> into the crowd, killing 6 strikers and fatally wounding 3.<ref name="morewood-oldminer"/> |---- |July 6, 1892 |Homestead, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Steel | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|9 |[[Homestead Massacre]]: An attempt by 300 [[Pinkerton Agency|Pinkerton]] guards hired by the company to enter the [[Carnegie Steel]] plant via the river was repulsed by strikers. In the ensuing gun battle, 9 strikers and 7 Pinkerton guards were shot and killed. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 7, 1892"|July 1892 |Coeur d'Alene, ID | style="text-align: center;"|Hardrock mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|4 |[[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor strike of 1892]]: In July a union miner was killed by mine guards.<ref>{{cite report|author1=Taft, Philip|author2=Ross, Philip|title=American Labor Violence: Its Causes, Character, and Outcome|work=The History of Violence in America: A Report to the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence|editor-first1=Hugh Davis| editor-last1=Graham|editor-first2=Ted Robert|editor-last2=Gurr|year=1969|publisher=Frederick A. Praeger}}</ref> Company guards also fired into a saloon where union men were sheltering, killing 3. |---- |June 9, 1893 |near Lemont, Illinois | style="text-align: center;"|Construction | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|4 |Dozens were injured and five were killed when quarrymen and canal workers clashed with replacement workers, local law enforcement, and two regiments of the [[Illinois National Guard]] during construction of the [[Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal]].<ref name="Strikers Come to Grief">{{cite news|title=Strikers Come to Grief|url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=LAH18930610.2.5|accessdate=23 April 2016|publisher=Los Angeles Herald|date=10 June 1893}}</ref> Four of the five were strikers: Gregor Kilka, Jacob (or Ignatz) Ast,<ref>{{cite news|title=Altgeld Inquiries What is the Matter on the Drainage Canal|url=http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=RIA18930612.1.4#|accessdate=23 April 2016|publisher=Rock Island Argus|date=12 June 1893}}</ref> Thomas Moorski, and Mike Berger<ref name="Strikers Come to Grief"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Much Bloodshed|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/iowa/waterloo/iowa-state-reporter/1893/06-15/page-7?tag=john+kluga+shot+santa+fe+railroad|accessdate=23 April 2016|publisher=Iowa State Reporter|date=15 June 1893}}</ref> |---- |May 23, 1894 |Uniontown, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Coal | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5.1"|5+ |The [[Bituminous coal miners' strike of 1894]] was organized by the [[United Mine Workers]] in multiple mid-Western states on April 21, ending in late June. Among many other violent incidents in Illinois, Ohio, and elsewhere, five strikers were killed and eight wounded by guards near [[Uniontown, Pennsylvania]] on May 23.<ref>W. T. Stead, Incidents of Labor War in America, [https://books.google.com/books?id=jpHQAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA69 The Contemporary Review], Vol. LXVI, No. 1, July 1894; pages 65–74.</ref> |---- |July 7, 1894 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="13"|30 or more estimated |[[Pullman Strike]]: An attempt by [[Eugene V. Debs]] to unionize the Pullman railroad car company in suburban Chicago developed into a strike on May 10, 1894. Other unions were drawn in. On June 26 a national rail strike of 125,000 workers paralyzed traffic in 27 states for weeks. By July 3 a mob peaking at perhaps 10,000 had gathered near the shoreline in south Chicago embarking on several straight days of vandalism and violence, burning switchyards and hundreds of railroad cars. Thousands of federal troops and deputy marshals were inserted over the governor's protests and clashed with rioters. The strike dissolved by August 2. Debs biographer [[Ray Ginger]] calculated thirty people killed in Chicago alone.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ray Ginger|title=Eugene V. Debs |year=1962|publisher=Macmillan |page=170|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Historian David Ray Papke, building on the work of Almont Lindsey published in 1942, estimated another 40 killed in other states.<ref>{{cite book|author=David Ray Papke|title=The Pullman Case: The Clash of Labor and Capital in Industrial America. Landmark law cases & American society|year=1999|publisher=University Press of Kansas|pages=35–37|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Property damage exceeded $80 million.<ref>{{cite book|author=John R. Commons|title=History of Labour in the United States'' vol 2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6J1ShTnok40C&pg=PA502|year=1918|publisher=Macmillan |page=502|display-authors=etal}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1896"|1896–1897 |Leadville, CO | style="text-align: center;"|Silver mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5.99"|as many as 11 |[[Leadville Miners' strike]]: The union asked for a wage increase of 50 cents-per-day for those making less than $3-per-day, to restore a 50-cent cut imposed in 1893. The county sheriff and his deputies supported the strikers. Leadville city police took the side of the mine owners, recruited new officers from Denver, and "apparently kept up a near-constant campaign of harassment and violence against union members throughout the strike." As many as six union men were killed during the strike, by strikebreakers, police, or under mysterious circumstances. Four more union men died when they joined about 50 strikers in a nighttime rifle and dynamite attack on the Coronado and Emmett mines; the attackers burned the Coronado shafthouse and killed a firefighter trying to extinguish the blaze.<ref>{{cite book|first=William P.|last=Philpott|title=The Lessons of Leadville, or, Why the Western Federation of Miners turned left|publisher=Colorado Historical Society|year=1995|pages=38–39}}</ref> |---- |September 10, 1897 |Lattimer, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|19 |[[Lattimer Massacre]]: 19 unarmed striking Polish, Lithuanian and Slovak coal miners were killed and 36 wounded by the Luzerne County sheriff's posse for refusing to disperse during a peaceful march. Most were shot in the back. |---- |October 12, 1898 |Virden, IL | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|8 |[[Virden Massacre]]: The Chicago-Virden Coal Company attempted to break a strike by importing black replacement workers. After union workers stopped a train transporting non-union workers and a tense standoff, eight of the union workers were killed when [[Thiel Detective Service Company|guards]] opened fire from the train. Six guards were also killed and 30 persons were wounded.<ref name="archive20141010160852">{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |title=Today in Labor History |author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute |location=Rochester, New York |accessdate=2015-09-16 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010160852/http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |archivedate=October 10, 2014 }}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="May 1, 1899"|started May 1899 |Coeur d'Alene, ID | style="text-align: center;"|Hardrock mining | style="text-align: center;"|organizing drive | style="text-align: center;"|3 |[[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor confrontation of 1899]]: Following a mass attack in which a non-union ore mill was destroyed by dynamite, and two men were shot and killed by union miners, [[William McKinley|President McKinley]] sent in U.S. Army troops, who, upon the order of Idaho officials, arrested nearly every adult male. About 1000 men were confined in a pine board prison surrounded by a 6-foot barbed wire fence patrolled by armed soldiers. Most were released within a week, but more than a hundred remained for months, and some were held until December 1899. Three workers died in the primitive conditions.<ref>{{cite book|first=J. Anthony|last=Lukas|title=Big Trouble: A Murder in a Small Western Town Sets Off a Struggle for the Soul of America|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=1997|page=111}}</ref><ref>"Dynamiters discharged and bullpen deserted," ''Idaho Statesman'', Dec. 3, 1899, p.1 c.3.</ref> |---- |June 10, 1900 |St. Louis, MO | style="text-align: center;"|Streetcar | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="3.1"|3 or more |[[St. Louis Streetcar Strike of 1900]]: The Police Board swore in 2500 citizens in a posse commanded by John H. Cavender, who had played a similar paramilitary role in the 1877 general strike. On the evening of June 10, men of that posse fatally shot three strikers returning from a picnic and left 14 others wounded. Between May 7 and the end of the strike in September, 14 people had been killed. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 3, 1901"|July 3, 1901 |Telluride, CO | style="text-align: center;"|Mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|4 |About 250 armed striking union miners took hidden positions around an entrance to the Smuggler-Union mine complex, and demanded that the nonunion miners leave the mine. One striker and two strikebreakers died in the ensuing gunfight. The strikers were more numerous and better-armed, and after several hours, the strikebreakers agreed to surrender, and assistant company manager Arthur Collins agreed to stop work at the mine. The following year, Collins was killed by a shotgun fired through a window into his home.<ref>Louis Adamic, [https://libcom.org/history/battles-telluride-mines-1901-1903-louis-adamic Telluride mines 1901-1903 B''attles in the Telluride Mines''], Library of Congress, 14 June 2014.</ref>
|---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 30, 1901"|July 30 through October 2, 1901 |San Francisco, CA | style="text-align: center;"|Multiple | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Waterfront workers struck beginning July 30, an action that triggered sympathy strikes from bakers, sailors and other sectors. The city was in a commercial standstill by late August, with hundreds of ships stacked up in the bay unable to unload, while a violent struggle played out on the streets. Four were killed (of whom two were strikers), and some 250 were wounded.<ref>{{cite book|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|first=Kevin|last=Starr|year=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0195118025 |page=26|quote=By late August 200 ships stood idle in the bay in a shutdown estimated to be costing California a net loss of $1 million a day. Mayor James Duval Phelan was forced to hire 200 special police to escort non-striking teamsters around the city. Five men died as a result of violent clashes, and more than 250 serious assaults were reported.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Industrial Relations in the San Francisco Bay Area, 1900-1918|last=Knight|first= Robert Edward Lee|pages=85–86|year=1960|publisher=University of California Press|quote=By the end of September the City Front strike had brought San Francisco two months of violent industrial conflict, during which two strikebreakers and two strikers had been killed, and several hundred men had been injured, some quite seriously.}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="July 1, 1902"|July 1, 1902, and October 1, 1902 |Pennsylvania | style="text-align: center;"|Coal | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|at least 2 |The [[Coal Strike of 1902]] in Pennsylvania caused about eight known casualties, two of them confirmed as strikers. On July 1, [[Coal and Iron Police]] guarding a Lehigh Valley Coal Company colliery in [[Old Forge, Lackawanna County, Pennsylvania|Old Forge]] were attacked by nighttime gunfire. The guards returned fire, and the next morning immigrant striker Anthony Giuseppe was found dead by a gunshot outside the site.<ref>{{cite news|title=Striker Shot Dead by Police|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/76079668/|accessdate=25 March 2016|agency=Daily News from Mount Carmel, Pennsylvania|date=July 2, 1902}}</ref> On October 9, a striker named William Durham was loitering near a non-striker's house, which had been partly destroyed by dynamite the previous week, when a soldier ordered him to halt. He refused, and the soldier shot and killed him.<ref>{{cite news|title=Soldier Kills a Striker|url=http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=RIA19021009.1.1#|accessdate=25 March 2016|agency=The Rock Island Argus, Volume 51, Number 303|date=9 October 1902|page= 1}}</ref> |---- |February 25, 1903 |Stanaford, West Virginia | style="text-align: center;"|Coal | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|6 |In the so-called Battle of Stanaford a volunteer armed posse of 30 led by federal, county and [[Baldwin–Felts Detective Agency|labor detectives]] conducted a dawn raid against a houseful of black striking coal miners, shooting three of them to death. Another three white strikers were also killed in related violence.<ref>The West Virginia Encyclopedia, entry "Battle of Stanaford", written by Lois C. McLean, last revised October 29, 2010, online at http://www.wvencyclopedia.org/articles/547</ref> |---- |June 8, 1904 |Dunnville, CO | style="text-align: center;"|Hardrock mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[Colorado Labor Wars]]: In December 1903, the governor declared martial law.<ref>{{cite book|title=All That Glitters: Class, Conflict, and Community in Cripple Creek (Working Class in American History)|first=Elizabeth|last=Jameson|year=1998|page=212|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0252066900}} Jameson states that Peabody later called it "qualified martial law." Suggs suggests that Adjutant General [[Sherman Bell]] interpreted the declaration as martial law.</ref> The Colorado National Guard, under Adjutant General [[Sherman Bell]], took the side of the mine owners against the miners. Bell announced that "the military will have sole charge of everything ..." and suspended the Bill of Rights, including freedom of assembly and the right to bear arms. Union leaders were arrested and either thrown in the bullpen, or banished.<ref>{{cite book|title=Colorado's War on Militant Unionism, James H. Peabody and the Western Federation of Miners|first=George G.|last=Suggs|year=1972|pages=105–106|isbn=978-0806123967}}</ref> The ''Victor Daily Record'' was placed under military censorship; all [[Western Federation of Miners|WFM]]-friendly information was prohibited. On June 8, 130 armed soldiers and deputies went to the small mining camp of Dunnville, 14 miles south of Victor, to arrest union miners. When they arrived, 65 miners were stationed behind rocks and trees on the hills above the soldiers. One of the miners shot at the troops, who returned fire. There were 7 minutes of steady gunfire, followed by an hour of occasional gunfire. Miner John Carley was killed in the gunfight. The much better-armed soldiers prevailed, and arrested 14 of the miners.<ref>Carroll D Wright, [https://books.google.com/books?id=lZ41AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA260&lpg=PA260&dq=dunnville+colorado+labor+union&source=bl&ots=cHZZUhT39s&sig=vQz7MFendUxyG_OWSiUFvO7kPUQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjG-PiL_OnLAhWCmIMKHbszCFkQ6AEIPDAF#v=onepage&q=dunnville%20colorado%20labor%20union&f=false A Report on Labor Disturbances in the State of Colorado], US Senate Document 122, 58th Congress, 3rd Session, Jan. 27 1905.</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Colorado Labor Wars: Cripple Creek 1903-1904, A Centennial Commemoration|author= Pikes Peak Library District|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OFTzZXM931YC#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2015-09-10|isbn= 9781567352238|year= 2006}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="April 7, 1905"|April 7–July, 1905 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|Garment mfg., Teamsters | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="21"|as many as 21 |[[1905 Chicago Teamsters' strike]]: Riots erupted on April 7 and continued almost daily until mid-July. Sometimes thousands of striking workers would clash with strikebreakers and armed police each day. By late July, when the strike ended, 21 people had been killed and a total of 416 injured.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite book|publisher=PublicAffairs|last=Fitch|first=Robert|title=Solidarity for Sale: How Corruption Destroyed the Labor Movement and Undermined America's Promise|year=2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=David|last=Witwer|title=Corruption and Reform in the Teamsters Union (Working Class in American History)|year=2003|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0252075131}}</ref><ref name="History">{{cite news|title=History of Great Teamsters' Strike Filled with Sensational Incidents|work=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=July 21, 1905}}</ref> |---- |February 19, 1907 |Milwaukee, WI | style="text-align: center;"|Ironworking | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Strike leader Peter J. Cramer of the [[International Molders and Foundry Workers Union of North America|International Molders Union]] was targeted and severely beaten by "labor detectives" hired by [[Allis-Chalmers]]. He died of his injuries on December 10, 1907. His attacker was tried for assault, his wife reached an out-of-court settlement with Allis-Chalmers, and the killing exposed a pattern of armed intimidation of strikers.<ref>"History of a Criminal Conspiracy Against Union Workmen", testimony of union official [[John P. Frey]] before the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary]], proceedings published as "Limiting Federal Injunctions, Volumes 1-5", U.S. GPO, 1914, page 367</ref> |---- |May 7, 1907 |San Francisco, CA | style="text-align: center;"|Streetcar | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="2.5"|2 to 6 |[[San Francisco Streetcar Strike of 1907]]:As the strike loomed, United Railroads contracted with the nationally known "King of the Strikebreakers", [[History of union busting in the United States#James Farley inherits the strikebreaker title|James Farley]], for four hundred replacement workers. Farley's armed workers took control of the entire streetcar system. Violence started two days into the strike when a shootout on Turk Street left 2 dead and about 20 injured. Of the 31 deaths from shootings and streetcar accidents, 25 were among passengers. |---- |December 25, 1908 |Stearns, KY | style="text-align: center;"|Coal | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |On Christmas Day U.S. Marshals battled a number of union organizers at the McFerrin Hotel in Stearns as they sought to arrest Berry Simpson. The hotel was set ablaze by order of the marshal,<ref>see resulting 1911 insurance case, American Central Insurance Company vs. Stearns Lumber Company, 145 Ky. 245, {{cite book|title=The Southwestern Reporter|date=1912|publisher=West Publishing Company|page=148|edition=vol. 140|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KSa5yMSEVMgC|accessdate=31 March 2016}}</ref> leaving the hotel burned out, many wounded, and two shot dead: Deputy U.S. Marshal John Mullins and organizer Richard Ross. The employer was the Stearns Coal Company, and the organizers attached to the [[United Mine Workers]].<ref>{{cite news|title=No Surrender, Say Miners|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1908/12/28/104776454.pdf|accessdate=31 March 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=28 December 1908}}</ref> |---- |May 1, 1909 |Great Lakes region | style="text-align: center;"|Maritime workers | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|5 |Three maritime unions, primarily the Lake Seamen's Union, struck a multistate Great Lakes shipping cartel called the Lake Carriers' Association. By late November 1909 five union members had been "shot and killed by strikebreakers and private police." <ref>Coast Seamen's Journal, Vol XXIII, no 13, December 15, 1909, pages 2,7. The names of the five: James O'Rourke, Richard Brown, William Woods, Matthew Dwyer, George Houghton.</ref> The difficult and fruitless strike dragged on until 1912. |---- |August 22, 1909 |McKees Rocks, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="4.5"|4 to as many as 8 |[[Pressed Steel Car strike of 1909]]: At least 12 people died when strikers battled with private security agents and Pennsylvania State Police mounted on horseback.<ref>{{cite book|first=Charles|last=McCollester|title=The Point of Pittsburgh: Production and Struggle at the Forks of the Ohio|page=184|year=2008|publisher=Battle of Homestead Foundation|isbn=978-0981889412}}</ref> Eight men died on August 22, including 4 strikers. By the time the rioting was over, a dozen men were dead and more than 50 were wounded. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="March 9, 1910"|March 9, 1910 – July 1, 1911 |Westmoreland County, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="6.5"|6 (plus 9 miners' wives)<ref name="Norwood">{{cite book|last=Norwood|first=Stephen H.|title=Strikebreaking and Intimidation: Mercenaries and Masculinity in Twentieth-Century America|year= 2002|publisher=The University of North Carolina Press|isbn=978-0807853733}}</ref> |[[Westmoreland County coal strike of 1910–1911]]: 70 percent of the miners were Slovak immigrants. Employers used force to intimidate striking miners, partially paying the cost for the Coal and Iron Police, local law enforcement and the Pennsylvania State Police. * May 8, 1910 – Yukon, PA: As 25 sheriff's deputies and state police vainly searched a boarding house, a crowd of striking miners gathered and ridiculed them. The deputies then fired into the crowd, killing one and injuring 30.<ref name="McDonough"/><ref name="Report">{{cite report|title=Report on the miners' strike in bituminous coal field in Westmoreland County, Pa., in 1910-11|editor-first=Walter B.|editor-last= Palmer|publisher=U.S. General Printing Office|location=Washington, DC| date=1912-06-22|isbn=978-1241007300}}</ref> * May 1910 – Export, PA: Miners who were walking home passed by coal company property, whereupon 20 sheriff's deputies and State Police attacked and severely beat them. One miner, trying to protect a child in his arms, was killed.<ref name="McDonough"/> * May 1910 – State police stopped four immigrant miners who did not speak English to question them. A bilingual miner came by and told the four to leave, but the troopers chased, shot and killed the fifth man, allegedly in cold blood.<ref name="McDonough"/><ref name="Report"/> * July 1910 – South Greensburg: Striking miners had obtained a permit to march, but as they began, deputy sheriffs on horseback stopped them. In defiance of the local police chief, the deputies charged with their horses, swinging clubs and then firing into the crowd, killing a miner. * A legislator's survey found that violence significantly increased after the arrival of the State Police, and that almost all acts of violence committed by state troopers were without provocation:<ref name=McDonough>{{cite journal|first=Judith|last=McDonough|title=Worker Solidarity, Judicial Oppression, and Police Repression in the Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania Coal Miner's Strike, 1910–1911|work=Pennsylvania History – A Journal of Mid-Atlantic Studies|volume=64|number=3|date=Summer 1997|url=http://journals.psu.edu/phj/article/view/25394/25163}}</ref> :* Mounted State Police routinely charged onto sidewalks or into crowds, severely injuring men, women and children.<ref name="Report"/> :* Severe beatings of citizens and striking miners for no reason were common, with troopers resisting local police attempts to stop them and breaking into homes without warrants.<ref name="McDonough"/><ref name="Report"/> :* State Police troopers shot up towns and fired indiscriminately into crowds and tent cities (killing and wounding sleeping women and children).<ref name="Norwood"/> |---- |July 28, 1910 |Brooklyn, NYC, NY | style="text-align: center;"|Sugar Mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |A striking worker identified as Walla Noblowsky was shot multiple times and died instantly when a labor action against [[American Sugar Refining Company]] became a neighborhood melee, with outnumbered police dodging bricks thrown from tenement roofs. Thirty more were hurt.<ref>"One Dead, Many Shot in Sugar Strike Riot.", New York Times, July 29, 1910, page 1</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="December 3, 1910"|December 3 and 15, 1910 |Chicago, IL | style="text-align: center;"|Garment workers | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Two of the five people killed in the [[1910 Chicago Garment workers' strike]] were strikers killed by private detectives. The first was Charles Lazinskas, killed by a private detective on December 3, and Frank Nagreckis was shot and killed by a special policeman while picketing on the 15th.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Leo Wolman|first1=et. al.|title=The clothing workers of Chicago, 1910-1922|date=1922|publisher=Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America. Research Dept|page=32|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mJguAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA32|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref> |---- |January 29, 1912 |Lawrence, MA | style="text-align: center;"|Textile | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[1912 Lawrence textile strike]]: A police officer fired into a crowd of strikers, killing [[Anna LoPizzo]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The I.W.W., its first seventy years (1905-1975). The history of an effort to organize the working class. A corrected facsimile of the 1955 volume: The I.W.W. its first fifty years by Fred Thompson with new chapter by Patrick Murfin on I.W.W. 1955-1975 and an appendix listing sources on I.W.W. history published since 1955.|first1=Fred W.|last1=Thompson|first2=Patrick|last2= Murfin|year=1976|page=56|publisher=Industrial Workers of the World|location=Chicago}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=William Dudley|last= Haywood|title=Autobiography of Big Bill Haywood|year=1929|page=249|publisher= International Publishers|isbn=978-0717800124}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="March 28, 1912"|March 28, 1912; May 7, 1912 |San Diego, CA | style="text-align: center;"|- | style="text-align: center;"|[[free speech fight|free speech demonstrations]] | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|2 |In the [[San Diego free speech fight]], Michael Hoy died after a police assault in jail,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bovokoy|first1=Matthew|title=The San Diego World's Fairs and Southwestern Memory, 1880-1940|date=2005|publisher=UNM Press|page=33}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | date=April 2, 1999 | first1=Carey | last1=McWilliams | title=California: The Great Exception | publisher=Univ of California Press | page=146}}</ref> and Joseph Mikolash, was killed by police in the IWW headquarters in San Diego on May 7.<ref>{{cite news|title=Assassins Attack and Wound Two Policemen|publisher=San Diego Union|date=May 8, 1912}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="April 18, 1912"|April 18, 1912–July 1913 |Kanawha County, WV | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="50"|up to 50 violent deaths (estimated) |[[Paint Creek Mine War]]: a confrontation between striking coal miners and coal operators in Kanawha County, West Virginia, centered on the area between two streams, Paint Creek and Cabin Creek.<ref>{{cite web|last=Meredith |first=Henry |url=http://paxflood.com/paintcreek/PaintCreekAugust31st.pdf |title=Paint Creek Mine War 1911-1923 |date=31 August 2005 |accessdate=2015-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150506202539/http://paxflood.com/paintcreek/PaintCreekAugust31st.pdf |archivedate=6 May 2015 |df= }}</ref> 12 miners were killed on July 26, 1912 at Mucklow. On February 7, 1913, the county sheriff's posse attacked the Holly Grove miners' camp with machine guns, killing striker Cesco Estep. Many more than 50 deaths among miners and their families were indirectly caused, as a result of starvation and malnutrition.<ref name="Steel">Steel, Edward M. ''The court-martial of Mother Jones'', page 61</ref> |---- |July 7, 1912 |Grabow, LA | style="text-align: center;"|Lumber | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|4 |[[Grabow Riot]]: Galloway Lumber Company guards fired on striking demonstrators of the [[Brotherhood of Timber Workers]], causing 4 deaths (including Decatur Hall) and 50 wounded. |---- |April 24, 1913 |Hopedale, MA | style="text-align: center;"|Automatic Loom mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |1 worker named Emidio Bacchiocci killed while picketing during strike at the Draper Company<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hope1842.com/draperstrikemilfbook.html|title=The Draper Strike of 1913|accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref> |---- |June 11, Fruit Company]], killing one and wounding 2 others.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.thepeoplesvoice.org/TPV3/Voices.php/2011/02/25/union-busting-in-america|title=Union Busting in America|first=Stephen|last=Lendman|publisher=thepeoplesvoice.org|accessdate=2015-09-19|date=February 25, 2011}}</ref> |---- |June 29, 1913 |Paterson, NJ | style="text-align: center;"|Textile | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Two were killed in the [[1913 Paterson silk strike]]: bystander Valentino Modestino fatally shot by a 14, 1913 |Seeberville, MI | style="text-align: center;"|Copper mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |[[Copper Country strike of 1913–1914]]: Sheriff's deputies visited a boarding house with the intent to arrest one of the boarders who had trespassed on company property while taking a shortcut home. The suspect, John Kalan, resisted arrest and went inside the house. As the deputies prepared to leave, someone tossed a bowling pin at them. The deputies opened fire into the crowded home, killing Alois Tijan and Steve Putich and injuring two others. The people inside the house were unarmed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reuther.wayne.edu/node/11074|title=Copper Country Strike, Violence, "Seeberville Affair" 1913|accessdate=2015-09-20|date=17 December 2013|publisher=Walter P. After the [[Ludlow Massacre]] in April 1914, for ten days striking miners at the other tent colonies went to war. They attacked and destroyed mines, fighting pitched battles with mine guards and militia along a 40-mile front from Trinidad to Walsenburg. The strike ended in defeat for the [[UMWA]] in December 1914. |---- |November 4, 1913 |Indianapolis, IN | style="text-align: center;"|Streetcar | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|4 |[[Indianapolis streetcar strike of 1913]]: The Terminal and Traction Company hired 300 professional strikebreakers from the [[Pinkerton Agency]] to operate the streetcars. When the strikebreakers attempted to move the streetcars into their carhouses, the crowd attacked the policemen who were protecting the strikebreakers. Strikebreakers then opened fire on the crowd, killing four. |---- |April 20, 1914 |Ludlow, CO | style="text-align: center;"|Mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5.5"|5 (plus 2 women, 12 children) |[[Ludlow Massacre]]: On Greek Easter morning, 177 company guards engaged by [[John D. Rockefeller, Jr.]] and other mine operators, and sworn into the State Militia just for the occasion, attacked a union tent camp with machine guns, then set it afire. Luka Vahernik, 50, was shot in the head. [[Louis Tikas]] and two other miners were captured, shot and killed by the militia. 5 miners, 2 women and 12 children in total died in the attack. |---- |January 19, 1915 |Carteret, NJ | style="text-align: center;"|Fertilizer mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|5 |[[Anti-union violence|Leibig Fertilizer strike]]: In an unprovoked attack, 40 deputies fired on strikers at the Williams & Clark Fertilizing Company after the strikers had stopped a train to check for strikebreakers and had found none.<ref>New York Times. "1 KILLED, 20 SHOT BY STRIKE GUARDS; Deputies Drive Off Laborers at the Liebig Fertilizer Works in Carteret, N.J.". Sharpe}}</ref> |---- |August 2, 1915 |Massena, NY | style="text-align: center;"|Aluminum | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |In 1915, workers revolted at the Mellon family's aluminum mill and took over every section of the plant. The sheriff of St. Lawrence County deputized businessmen to break the strike. New York [[Charles S. Whitman|Governor Whitman]] sent in three companies of the state militia, armed with bayonets, to disperse a crowd of hundreds of workers. The following day, striker Joseph Solunski died of a gunshot wound in an Ogdensburg hospital.<ref>{{cite news|title=MILITIA CONTROLS MASSENA.; Fifteen Arrests Made for Rioting -- Trouble Seems Near End|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0DE4DE1138E633A25750C0A96E9C946496D6CF|accessdate=13 April 2017|publisher=New York Times|date=3 August 1915}}</ref><ref name=ww>{{cite web|url=http://www.workers.org/2009/us/mellons_0820/|title=The Mellon family war against workers: Coal mines and machine guns|first=Stephen|last=Millies|date=8 August 2009|accessdate=2015-09-20|publisher =Workers World|location=New York}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1916"|January 1916 |East Youngstown, OH | style="text-align: center;"|Steel | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|3 |[[Youngstown Strike of 1916]]: When two trainloads of strikebreakers from the South were smuggled into the Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. plant, angry strikers assembled at the mill gates. Mill guards fired into the crowd, killing 3 strikers. A riot then began that burned six square blocks of the city. A grand jury found that the guards had precipitated the disturbance.<ref name= steel>{{cite book|title=Labor and Steel|first=Horace B.|last=Davis|url=https://archive.org/details/laborandsteel00davirich|publisher=International Publishers Co.|location=New York|year=1933}}</ref>{{rp|239–240}} |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="May 1, 1916"|May 1916 |Braddock, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Steel | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Strikers had arranged to parade outside the Carnegie Steel Co. plant, but the company had stationed an armed force inside the plant. When the paraders arrived, the guards opened fire, shooting strikers and bystanders. Two strikers were killed.<ref name= steel/><sup>pp. 240–241</sup> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="June 22, 1916"|June−July, 1916 | data-sort-value="Chisholm" |Area of Chisholm, MN | style="text-align: center;"|Iron mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|3 |[[Mesabi Range#Labor strikes|Mesabi Range strike of 1916]]: On June 22, 1916, in Virginia, MN, miner John Alar was shot and killed in a confrontation between police and a group of pickets.<ref>{{cite journal|title=THE 1916 MINNESOTA MINERS' STRIKE AGAINST U.S. STEEL|first=Robert M.|last= Eleff|work=Minnesota History|date=Summer 1988|pages=63–74|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society}}</ref><ref name="UWA"/> Shortly afterward, a miner left his shift after being paid less than the contracted rate, helping to ignite the Mesabi Range strike of 1916. The [[IWW]] supported the strike for better pay and shorter hours. On July 3, a clash between guards and several strikers left a guard and a bystander dead.<ref name=filipelli/>{{rp|331}}<ref>{{cite book|title=Davis (1933)|page=238|quote=A group of deputized gunmen went to a miner's house, and a fight started in which two men were killed. A miner was shot and killed on the picket line. The strike ended without a settlement ...}}</ref>{{rp|238}} |---- |November 5, 1916 |Everett, WA | style="text-align: center;"|Shingle mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5.1"|5 or more |[[Everett Massacre]]: 200 citizen deputies under the authority of the Snohomish County sheriff waited for the arrival by passenger ship of [[Industrial Workers of the World|IWW]] workers coming to support the strikers. Two deputies were killed by fellow deputies{{dubious|date=March 2016}}.<ref name="McClelland">John McClelland Jr., ''Wobbly War: The Centralia Story'' (Tacoma: Washington State Historical Society, 1987)</ref><ref name="Lowell">Lowell S. Chief of Police [[Sid Hatfield]] tried to arrest the detectives for illegally evicting miners and carrying weapons. A gun battle ensued, resulting in the deaths of 7 private agents, 2 miners, and Mayor Cabel Testerman. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 4, 1920"|1920 |Philadelphia, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Shipping | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|5 |5 killed, 20 injured in longshoremen's strike<ref name=Ferguson/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |October 2, 1920 |Hannaford, ND | style="text-align: center;"|Railroad | style="text-align: center;"| | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Joe Bagley, a reportedly well-known member of the IWW, was shot and killed by Special Agent Nolan of the Great Northern railway.<ref name="UWA"/> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 13, 1920"|1920 |Walker County, Alabama | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="16"|at least 16 |[[1920 Alabama coal strike]]: The Alabama miners' strike was a statewide strike of the [[UMWA]] against coal mine operators. On December 23, 1920, local union official Adrian Northcutt of Nauvo was summoned out of his home by soldiers of Company M of the Alabama Guard, who fired 7 shots, killing him.<ref name=filipelli>{{cite book|title=Labor conflict in the United States, an encyclopedia|editor-last=Filipelli|editor-first=Ronald L.|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Inc.|location=New York|isbn=0-8240-7968-X}}</ref><sup>p. 9</sup> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1921"|1921 |Wheeling, WV | style="text-align: center;"|Steel | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Elmer Cost, a striker, was shot and killed by a guard.<ref name= steel/><sup>p. 251</sup> |---- |August 1, 1921 |Welch, WV | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="2"|2 (Chief of Police [[Sid Hatfield]] and Ed Chambers) |On the steps of the McDowell County Courthouse, the gunmen of the [[Baldwin-Felts|Baldwin-Felts Agency]] avenged the deaths of their colleagues by shooting to death two men as they and their wives prepared to enter the court building. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="August 25, 1921"|August 25–Sept. 2, 1921 |Logan County, WV | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike, organizing | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="51"|50–100 |[[Battle of Blair Mountain]]: the largest labor uprising in United States history and the largest organized armed uprising since the American Civil War. During an attempt by the miners to unionize, and following the murder of [[Sid Hatfield]], 10,000 armed coal miners confronted 3000 lawmen and [[Baldwin-Felts]] strikebreakers, who were backed by coal mine operators. In the summer of 1921 in [[Mingo County, West Virginia|Mingo County]], hundreds of miners were arrested without [[habeas corpus]] and other basic legal rights. Talk spread of a march to free those confined miners, end martial law, and organize the county. In [[Kanawha County, West Virginia|Kanawha County]], up to 13,000 miners gathered and began marching toward [[Logan County, West Virginia|Logan County]] on August 24. The reviled anti-union sheriff of Logan County, [[Don Chafin]]<ref>The Herald-Dispatch. [http://www.wvculture.org/History/government/chafindon01.html "Funeral Rites Thursday For Colorful Don Chafin"], August 10, 1954.</ref> set up defenses on Blair Mountain, with the nation's largest private armed force of 2000. By August 29, battle was fully joined. Chafin's men, though outnumbered, had the advantage of higher positions and better weaponry. Private hired planes dropped homemade bombs on the miners near the towns of Jeffery, Sharples and Blair. Army bombers were used for aerial surveillance. Sporadic gun battles continued for a week. Up to 30 deaths were reported by Chafin's side and 50–100 on the union miners' side, with hundreds more injured. On September 2, federal troops arrived by presidential order, and the miners started heading home the next day. About one million rounds were fired in the battle.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2015-09-13|url=http://archive.archaeology.org/1201/features/blair_mountain_coal_activism_west_virginia.html|volume=65|number=1|date=January–February 2012|first=Samir S.|last=Patel|title=Mountaintop Rescue – Archaeology, coal, and activism collide in the Appalachian Mountains at the site of America's largest labor conflict|work=Archaeology}}</ref> |---- |August 27, 1921 |Sharples, WV | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|arrest attempt | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="2.1"|at least 2 |Posse of 70 to 100 deputies and state police went to the small mining community of Sharples to arrest miners and their leaders. The confrontation resulted in a gunfight in which at least two miners were killed and two others were wounded. |---- |June 22, 1922 |Herrin, IL | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|22 |[[Herrin Massacre]]: Several hundred armed UMWA strikers laid siege to a nonunion mine. After an afternoon of gunfire by both sides, three of the besieging strikers were dead or mortally wounded. The next morning, the approximately 50 strikebreakers agreed to surrender their arms in exchange for a guarantee of safe passage out of the county. After the disarmed strikebreakers left the mine, 19 were killed by the strikers in various ways; some were killed in the town cemetery, in front of a crowd of about 1,000 cheering townspeople. Some were tied up and repeatedly shot at close range; some had their throats slit.<ref>[http://www.dailyregister.com/article/20120622/NEWS/306229950 "Herrin Massacre still stands out 90 years later,"] Harrisburg (Penn.) ''Daily Register'', 22 June 2012.</ref><ref name="wieck">{{cite book|first=David Thoreau|last=Wieck|title=Woman from Spillertown: a memoir of Agnes Burns Wieck|publisher=Southern Illinois University Press|year=1992|pages=82–84|isbn=978-0809316199}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Federal Writers' Project|title=Illinois: A Descriptive and Historical Guide|publisher=A.C. McClurg & Company|location=Chicago|year=1939|page=453}}</ref> |---- |August 2, 1922 |Buffalo, NY | style="text-align: center;"|Streetcar | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |John Chrosniak, a striking streetcar conductor, was killed when a city patrolman on a moving streetcar fired four shots into an obstructing crowd of 20 protesters throwing stones. The motorman was also sprayed with acid in the incident.<ref>{{cite news|title=Buffalo Striker Killed|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/08/03/99049920.pdf|accessdate=29 March 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=3 August 1922}}</ref> |---- |September 9, 1924 |Hanapēpē, Kaua{{okina}}i, HI | style="text-align: center;"|Sugar | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|16 |[[Hanapepe massacre|Hanapēpē massacre]]: Sixteen striking Filipino sugar workers on the Hawai{{okina}}i island of Kaua{{okina}}i were killed by police; four police also died. Many of the surviving strikers were jailed, then deported.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rick Baldoz|title=The Third Asiatic Invasion: Empire and Migration in Filipino America, 1898-1946|publisher=NYU Press|year=2011|page=58}}</ref> |---- |November 21, 1927 |Serene, CO | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|6 |[[Columbine Mine massacre]]: State police and mine guards fired pistols, rifles and a machine gun into a group of five hundred striking miners and their wives. |---- |February 9, 1929 |Imperial, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|police brutality | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Three members of the [[Coal and Iron Police]] beat miner [[John Barkoski]] to death. He had gone to his mother-in-law's home and there fell into the hands of two coal and iron policemen employed by the Pittsburgh Coal Company. Eyewitnesses said one of them had launched an unprovoked attack on Barkoski, who received a laceration of the left cheek, five or six head wounds, two broken ribs and a fractured nose. Later at police barracks over the course of four hours, according to trial testimony, a third officer beat Barkoski with a strap while he lay semiconscious on the floor, twisted his ears until the miner cried aloud, and twisted his broken nose until he lapsed again into unconsciousness. Then he beat Barkoski over the chest with a poker until the poker bent, straightened the implement and beat the man again. He stripped the miner to the waist in order to better use a strap and kicked Barkoski until the miner's body rolled over and over on the floor. The original attacker also beat Barkoski, kicked him, struck him over the head with knucklers, and slapped him on the arms and legs and neck with his blackjack. The next morning he was taken to a hospital where he died. A jury acquitted the three officers of murder.<ref name=ww/><ref>{{cite magazine|first=Frank|last= Butler|title=Coal and Iron Justice|work=The Nation|date=October 16, 1929|url=http://explorepahistory.com/odocument.php?docId=1-4-29A}}</ref> |---- |October 2, 1929 |Marion, NC | style="text-align: center;"|Textile | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|6 |A sheriff and 11 deputies attempting to disperse a picket line opened fire on strikers, killing 6 and wounding 17 others. Most of the dead and wounded were shot in the back.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mountainx.com/news/community-news/033011mountain-shame|title=Mountain shame: Remembering the Marion Massacre|date=March 29, 2011|first=Jake|last=Frankel|work=Mountain Xpress|location=Asheville, North Carolina|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1931"|1931–1939 |Harlan County, KY | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|various | style="text-align: center;"|13 |The [[Harlan County War]] was a violent, nearly decade-long conflict between miners and mine operators who adamantly resisted unionization. It consisted of skirmishes, executions, bombings, and strikes. New York Times. Nov 18, 1931. p. 18.</ref> Before its conclusion, state and federal troops would occupy the county more than half a dozen times.<ref>{{cite web|title=Remembering Bloody Harlan|url=http://parallelnarratives.com/remembering-bloody-harlan|accessdate=2015-09-10}}</ref> |---- |March 7, 1932 |Dearborn, MI | style="text-align: center;"|Auto | style="text-align: center;"|demonstration by unemployed workers | style="text-align: center;"|5 |[[Ford Massacre]]: Thousands of unemployed [[Hunger marches|hunger marchers]] sought to present petitions to [[Ford Motor Company]] at the end of a planned march to the Dearborn plant. Dearborn police and Ford security guards opened fire on the marchers. As protestors retreated, machine guns were fired at them. 4 workers were shot to death and over 60 were injured, many by gunshot wounds. |Ambridge, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Steel | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Executives at Jones & Laughlin Steel in Aliquippa, PA recruited a group of 200 At one point the guards fired guns, killing two strikers named Lee Wakefield and Harry Englemann. In addition, 47 "men, women and boys were wounded, gassed, and injured".<ref>{{cite news|title=Troops Restore Peace|url=http://content.wisconsinhistory.org/cdm/ref/collection/tp/id/64315|accessdate=24 March 2016|agency=Sheboygan Press|date=June 28, 1934}}</ref> |---- |June 30, 1934 |Seattle, WA | style="text-align: center;"|Shipping | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[1934 West Coast waterfront strike]]: Upon hearing that scab crews were about to take two oil tankers out of the port, union members went to the dock. Four were shot, one of whom died of his wounds.<ref>{{cite news|work =Voice of Action|url=http://depts.washington.edu/dock/images/news/VOA/VoA_1934-07-13_p1.jpg|title=Portland mayor laughs at blood soaked shirt of dying picket; communists call protest|date=July 13, 1934| accessdate=2015-09-10}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|propaganda, pure and simple|date=March 2016}} |---- |July 20, 1934 |Minneapolis, MN | style="text-align: center;"|Trucking, General | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |[[Minneapolis general strike of 1934]]: 50 armed policemen were escorting a non-union truck that was then cut off by a vehicle carrying picketers. The police opened fire on the vehicle with shotguns and then turned their guns on the strikers filling the streets. Two strikers were killed and 67 wounded. |---- |September 2, 1934 |Trion, GA | style="text-align: center;"|Textile | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[Textile workers strike (1934)]]: A picketer and mill guard died in a shootout. |---- |September 2, 1934 |Augusta, GA | style="text-align: center;"|Textile | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |[[Textile workers strike (1934)]]: Guards killed two picketers. |---- |September 6, 1934 |Honea Path, SC | style="text-align: center;"|Textile | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;"|7 |[[Textile workers strike (1934)]]: Deputies stationed in and around Chiquola Mill opened fire on picketing textile workers with pistols and shotguns.
