Police suspected striking hotel workers, but no arrests were made.<ref>[http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1938/02/26/page/2/article/police-set-limit-of-six-pickets-at-del-prado “Police set limit of six pickets at Del Prado,”] Chicago Daily Tribune, 26 Feb. 1938, p.2 c.3.</ref> |---- |September 9, 1938 |Hatboro, PA | style="text-align: center;"|Garment | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |Striker Raymond Cooke was killed at Oscar Nebel Hosiery Company, shot to death by the town's police chief.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shut Down Protest in Picket's Death|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/pennsylvania/uniontown/uniontown-morning-herald/1938/09-12/page-7?|accessdate=27 March 2016|agency=Morning Herald, Uniontown PA|date=September 12, 1938}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1940"|1940 |Ohio | style="text-align: center;"|Coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|1 |1 picketer killed, 2 wounded during coal strike<ref name=Ferguson/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="March 1, 1959"|March 1959 |Letcher and Perry Counties, Kentucky | style="text-align: center;"|Coal | style="text-align: center;"|Strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="3"|at least three |A [[United Mine Workers]] strike called on March 9 grew violent as the union used mass picketing tactics, and launched assaults against loading ramps using dynamite and arson. Firefights were common. At least three strikers were killed.<ref>{{cite book|title=Labor in the South|first=F. Ray |last=Marshall|publisher= Harvard University Press|year= 1967|page=286}}</ref> |}
===Execution by the state=== :{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; font-size:87%; border:1; cellpadding:5; cellspacing:0;" !scope="col" data-sort-type="date"|Date !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Type of dispute !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Workers executed by the State !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Notes |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="June 21, 1877"|June 21, 1877 – October 9, 1879<ref>{{cite book|title=Labor's Story in the United States|first=Philip Yale|last=Nicholson|year=2004|publisher=Temple University Press|page=108|isbn=9781592132393|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7I2dxUSB9WUC&pg=PA108&lpg=PA108&dq=%22milton+shapp%22+pardon+kehoe#v=onepage&q=%22milton%20shapp%22%20pardon%20kehoe&f=false}}</ref> |Pennsylvania (Pottsville, Mauch Chunk, Bloomsburg, Sunbury) | style="text-align: center;"|coal mining strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="20"|20 |A 20% pay cut in December, 1874, led to a long strike that began on January 1, 1875,<ref name=Boyer>{{cite book|title=Labor's Untold Story|last1=Boyer|first1=Richard O.|last2=Morais|first2=Herbert M.|publisher=United Workers|year=1974}}</ref><sup>p. 51</sup> and quickly turned violent. Several company bosses were killed. Bodies of militant miners were sometimes found in deserted mine shafts.<ref name=Boyer/><sup>p. 53</sup> 20 workers (suspected [[Molly Maguires]])<ref name=Kenny>{{cite book|last=Kenny|first=Kevin|title=Making Sense of the Molly Maguires|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0195116311|year=1998}}</ref><sup>pp. 5,10</sup> were tried for murder and convicted largely on testimony of a [[Pinkerton (detective agency)|Pinkerton]] spy.<ref name=Kenny/><sup>pp. 234–35</sup><ref name=Bloom/> Three of the defendants confessed: Manus Cull, Francis McHugh, and Patrick Butler, as did Molly Maguire member "Powder Keg" Kerrigan. Their confessions and testimony corroborated that of Pinkerton agent McParlan. Historians have written that the murder charge against John Keyhoe, the subject of a later trial, remains dubious.<ref>Prof. Douglas O. Linder, Famous trials: [http://law2.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/maguires/mollytrialaccount.html An account of the Molly Maguires], University of Missouri at Kansas City, 2010.</ref> [[Franklin B. Gowen]], owner of the Philadelphia & Reading Railroad and the person who hired Pinkerton, had himself appointed special prosecutor.<ref name=Boyer/><sup>p. 54</sup><ref>{{cite book|title=[[Political Repression in Modern America]]|author=Goldstein, Robert Justin|publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]]|year=2001|isbn=0-252-06964-1|page=29}}</ref> The 20 men were hanged by the State of Pennsylvania.
{{quote|The Molly Maguire trials were a surrender of state sovereignty. A private corporation initiated the investigation through a private detective agency. A private police force arrested the alleged defenders, and private attorneys for the coal companies prosecuted them. The state provided only the courtroom and the gallows. ... Any objective study of the tenor of the times and the entire record must conclude that (the Mollies) ... did not have fair and impartial juries. They were, therefore, denied one of the fundamental rights that [[William Penn]] guaranteed to all of Pennsylvania's citizens.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Hard Coal Docket: 150 Years of the Bench & Bar of Carbon County (1843-1993)|last=Lavelle|first=John P.|year=1994|publisher=Times News}}</ref>}}
Following an investigation 100 years after his death, John Kehoe was posthumously pardoned by [[Milton Shapp|the governor]], who wrote, "[I]t is impossible for us to imagine the plight of the 19th Century miners in Pennsylvania's anthracite region. ... We can be proud of the men known as the Molly Maguires",<ref name=Bloom>{{cite web|url=http://www.historynet.com/molly-macguires-in-pennsylvania-coal-regions.htm|first=Joseph|last=Bloom|title=Molly {{sic|MacGuires|nolink=y}} in Pennsylvania Coal Regions|date=June 12, 2006|accessdate=2015-09-12}}</ref> whom he praised as "these martyred men of labor".<ref name=Kenny/><sup>p. 284</sup> |---- |November 11, 1887 |Illinois | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5"|4 hanged on Nov. 11, 1887 ([[Albert Parsons]], [[August Spies]], [[George Engel]], [[Adolph Fischer]]) 1 suicide on Nov. 10, 1887 ([[Louis Lingg]]) |On May 4, 1886, one day after police fired into a crowd of striking McCormick Harvesting Machine workers outside Chicago, 3000 people rallied at Chicago's [[Haymarket affair|Haymarket Square]] to protest the police brutality.<ref name=TESAH/> A bomb thrown at the rally caused police to open fire, killing at least one worker and injuring many. Blamed for the Haymarket bomb, four labor leaders were eventually hanged and one committed suicide the day before the scheduled executions. The prosecution admitted that none of eight defendants was involved in the bombing. In 1893 Illinois Governor [[John Peter Altgeld]] found that "much of the evidence given in the trial was pure fabrication," and that the police had bribed and "terrorized ignorant men" or threatened witnesses "with torture if they refused to swear to anything desired."<ref>{{cite book|title=Labor's Untold Story|last1=Boyer|first1=Richard O.|last2=Morais|first2=Herbert M.|publisher=Marzani and Munsell, Inc.|year=1955|page=98}}</ref> |---- |November 19, 1915 |Utah | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="1"|[[Joe Hill]] |Joe Hill, [[IWW]] labor organizer and songwriter, was executed by firing squad by the State of Utah for the murder of a grocer, despite worldwide protests and two attempts to intervene by President [[Woodrow Wilson]]. With the backing of the IWW, his conviction was appealed to the Utah Supreme Court. Citing dozens of alleged errors in procedure and fairness, attorney O.N. Hilton called Hill's case "utterly lacking in the essential fundamentals of proof."<ref>{{cite book|first=Gibbs M.|last=Smith|title=Joe Hill|publisher=Peregrine Smith Books|year=1984|location=Salt Lake City, Utah|page=105}}</ref> Recent research findings support "that the circumstantial case made against the man who ultimately was executed for the crime was nowhere near as convincing as the one that could and should have been made against (Frank Z.) Wilson," who was a serial criminal well-known to police, who picked him up mere blocks from the murder, detained him and then let him go.<ref>{{cite book|first=William|last=Adler|publisher=Bloomsbury USA|year=2012|page=61|isbn=978-1608194605|title=The Man Who Never Died: The Life, Times, and Legacy of Joe Hill, American Labor Icon}}</ref> |---- |}
==By vigilante, strikers, mob and hate group==
:{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; font-size:87%; border:1; cellpadding:5; cellspacing:0;" !scope="col" |Date !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Industry !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Type of dispute !scope="col" style="text-align: center;"|Workers* killed by vigilante/mob !scope="col" class="unsortable"|Notes |---- |March 14, 1877 |Chico, CA | style="text-align: center;"|farming | style="text-align: center;"|race | style="text-align: center;"|4 |A group of white nativists organized as a "Laborers' Union" openly plotted assassination and arson before murdering four Chinese farmhands in a worker's cabin. Two survived to bear witness. Partly hate crime and partly labor conflict, this was one event in the attempted purge of Chinese immigrants from the U.S. west coast.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pfaelzer|first1=Jean|title=Driven Out: the Forgotten War Against Chinese Americans|date=2007|publisher=Random House|pages=61–72}}</ref> |---- |April 18, 1878 |Coal Creek, Indiana | style="text-align: center;"|coal | style="text-align: center;"|strike, race | style="text-align: center;"|3 |A long-standing "armed truce" had stood between striking coal miners and imported non-union black replacement workers at Coal Creek for about a year. Since November 1877 some of the strikers had joined a local volunteer militia, armed by the State arsenal. A drunken argument left one black worker shot to death in a saloon, two more assassinated in the streets, and many turned out of their homes.<ref>"Riotous Militiamen," [[New York Tribune]], April 19, 1878</ref><ref>A History of Indiana, Volume 2, by Logan Esarey, 1918, page 1072</ref> |---- |September 2, 1885 |Rock Springs, WY | style="text-align: center;"|coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|wage dispute, race | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="28"|28 or more |[[Rock Springs massacre]]: A riot between Chinese immigrant miners and white immigrant miners resulted from a labor dispute over the [[Union Pacific Coal Department]]'s policy of preferentially hiring Chinese miners and paying them lower wages than white miners. Racial tensions were a factor in the massacre. When the rioting ended, at least 28 Chinese miners were dead and 15 were injured. |---- |April 26, 1886 |Near Wyandotte, KS | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"| | style="text-align: center;"|2 |[[Great Southwest railroad strike of 1886]]: A sabotaged section of rail led to a fatal derailment, killing fireman William Carlisle and brakeman John Horton.<ref>{{cite book|title=The official history of the great strike of 1886 on the Southwestern railway system|date=1886|publisher=Missouri Bureau of Labor Statistics|page=113|url=https://archive.org/details/officialhistoryo00miss|accessdate=7 April 2016}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="September 2, 1889"|September 2–12, 1889 |Leflore County, Mississippi |style="text-align: center;"|farming |style="text-align: center;"|organization | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="6"|6 or more |The organization of a local chapter of the [[Colored Farmers' National Alliance and Cooperative Union]] under a man named Oliver Cromwell in 1888 drew the armed opposition of white authorities, planters and retailers.<ref name="ABC-CLIO">{{cite book|last1=Gallagher|first1=Charles A.|last2=Lippard|first2=Cameron D.|title=Race and Racism in the United States: An Encyclopedia of the American Mosaic|date=24 June 2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|page=1130|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GQlvBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA1130|accessdate=16 April 2017}}</ref> In the resulting "Leflore County Massacre"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Holmes|first1=William|title=The Leflore County Massacre and the Demise of the Colored Farmers' Alliance|journal=Phylon|date=1973|volume= 34| issue = 3|page=267|jstor=274185}}</ref> six prominent "insurgents" were captured, accused of various crimes, and made subject to summary executions and lynchings. "A welter of reports (placed) the number of black dead between 30 and 100."<ref>{{cite book|last1=John C.|first1=Willis|title=Forgotten Time: The Yazoo-Mississippi Delta After the Civil War|date=2000|publisher=University of Virginia Press|page=135|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s1hfSMdOLrkC&pg=PA135|accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref> |---- |September 25, 1891 |Lee County, AR | style="text-align: center;"|cotton | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|15 |African-American cotton workers organized the [[Cotton pickers strike of 1891]] for higher wages. Strikers killed two nonstriking cotton pickers on September 25, and killed a plantation manager three days later. In retaliation, a white mob killed 12 strikers, most of them by lynching.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |title=Today in Labor History |author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute |location=Rochester, New York |accessdate=2015-09-16 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927053637/http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |archivedate=September 27, 2013 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=4267 Cotton Pickers Strike of 1891], Encyclopedia of Arkansas, accessed April 11, 2016.</ref> |---- |March 12, 1895 |New Orleans, LA | style="text-align: center;"|longshoremen | style="text-align: center;"|labor competition | style="text-align: center;"|6 |Six non-union black longshoremen were shot and killed in the [[1895 New Orleans dockworkers riot]] as they loaded an ocean-going cotton vessel, attacked by a mob of union white competitors.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zeiger|first1=Robert H.|title=For Jobs and Freedom: Race and Labor in America Since 1865|date=2014|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UpjQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA41|accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> |---- |April 10, 1899 |Pana, IL | style="text-align: center;"|coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="7"|about 7 |In the [[Pana riot]], one of the incidents of the southern [[Illinois coal wars]], three-way conflict with a racial character among local white miners, newly settled unionized black miners, and non-union black miners resulted in an estimated seven killed and 28 more wounded. |---- |September 17, 1899 |Carterville, IL | style="text-align: center;"|coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|5 |In the last of the deadly incidents in the southern [[Illinois coal wars]], five black strikebreakers died in a gunfight while being chased by a crowd of striking white miners.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=S-mKwbU0XlEC&dq=carterville+mine+riots&source=gbs_navlinks_s Encyclopedia of American Race Riots], volume 2, page 674.</ref> Government troops were again summoned following the killings. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1902"|1902 |Hazleton, PA | style="text-align: center;"|coal mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|14 |14 non-union workers killed, 42 badly injured, at anthracite strike near Hazleton, PA<ref>{{cite journal|journal=The Rural New Yorker|volume=61|page=725}}</ref> |---- |October 17, 1905 |Newark, Ohio | style="text-align: center;"|metal workers | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|3 |Amid a string of assaults and injuries, three men were killed in separate incidents during a strike of Metal Polishers against the Wehrle Stove Company. Striker Michael Goodman was shot to death on October 17.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/70863393/|title= |accessdate=26 January 2018|publisher=Hocking Sentinel (Logan, Ohio)|date=19 October 1905}}</ref> Non-union worker Charles Higgins was killed on November 11.<ref>see State of Ohio v George Kerlin, {{cite book|title=Ohio Law Bulletin, Volume 51|date=1 January 1906|publisher=Laning Company|page=317|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8_xHAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA317|accessdate=26 January 2018}}</ref> And non-union polisher Homer Loar was shot and killed on December 21.<ref>{{cite news|title=POLICE Inadequate in Newark To Deal With the Trouble Growing Out of a Strike|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/32611789/|accessdate=26 January 2018|publisher=Cincinnati Inquirer|date=23 December 1905}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Third Murder From Polishers Strike at Newark, Thursday|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/284578183/|accessdate=26 January 2018|publisher=Times-Recorder, Zanesville, Ohio|date=22 December 1905}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1910"|1910 |Tampa, FL | style="text-align: center;"|cigar mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|5 |Five labor organizers were lynched in Tampa during 1910. The Committee for the Defense of Civil Rights in Tampa stated, "The Tampa cigar bosses carry on a constant campaign to prevent the organization of cigar makers unions."<ref name= cdcrt>{{cite report|title=Tampa – Tar and Terror|publisher=Committee for the Defense of Civil Rights in Tampa|location=New York City|year=1935|url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/u/ulsmanuscripts/pdf/31735061543876.pdf}}</ref><sup>p. 8</sup> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 9, 1911"|January 9–13, 1911 |Somerset, KY | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|racial labor rules | style="text-align: center;"|9 |White firemen of the [[Cincinnati, New Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway]] (part of the [[Queen and Crescent Route]]) struck on January 9, 1911, when the company refused their demand that their black counterparts be fired within 90 days. Trains continued to run, with black firemen on their crews, in the vicinity of [[Kings Mountain, Kentucky]], [[Somerset, Kentucky]], and [[Oakdale, Tennessee]], in terrain well-suited for sniper attacks. At least eleven people were killed by sharpshooters within four days, nine of them black railroad employees, and two detectives.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eleven Men Killed in Firemen's Strike|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/new-york/new-york/new-york-times/1911/03-13?tag=detective+james+carl+glenmary+1911|accessdate=2 April 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=13 March 1911}} Subsequent reports of a total twenty dead are harder to substantiate: see {{cite news|title=Twenty Dead Now in Firemen's Strike|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/new-york/new-york/new-york-times/1911/03-16/page-3?tag=detective+james+carl+glenmary+1911|accessdate=2 April 2016|agency=New York Times|date=16 March 1911}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="October 3, 1911"|October 3, 1911 through January 25, 1912 | Illinois, California, Utah, Mississippi | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|11 | Five of the twelve known casualties of the [[Illinois Central shopmen's strike of 1911]] were strikers: Robert Mitchell, Cairo Illinois, October 3;<ref>{{cite news|title=Strike Breakers are in Conflict|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/texas/laredo/laredo-weekly-times/1911/10-08/page-5?tag=houston+strike+pipes+killed+1911|accessdate=1 April 2016|publisher=Laredo (TX) Weekly Times|date=10 October 1911}}</ref> Lem Haley, McComb Mississippi, October 4;<ref>{{cite news|title=Troops at M'Comb Stop Strike Riots|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/new-york/new-york/new-york-times/1911/10-05?tag=truly+curtis+carl+canton+mccomb+1911|accessdate=2 April 2016|agency=New York Times|date=5 October 1911}}</ref> J.S. Coldereau, Bakersfield California, November 25, 1911;<ref name="U.S. Government Printing Office">{{cite book|title=Industrial Relations: Final Report and Testimony, United States Commission on Industrial Relations|date=1916|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|page=9878|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4aMsAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> John G. Hayden, Salt Lake City, December 5;<ref>{{cite news|title=Union Man Shot|url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19111206.2.75.3|accessdate=7 April 2016|issue=Volume 111, Number 6|publisher=San Francisco Call|date=6 December 1911}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Railway Carmen's Journal|date=1913|page=491|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yd5JAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA491|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> and Ed Lefevre, Mojave California, January 25.<ref name="U.S. Government Printing Office"/> Five replacement workers and one non-striking worker were also killed. |---- |August 3, 1913 |Wheatland, CA | style="text-align: center;"|agriculture | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |[[Wheatland Hop Riot]]: Fighting broke out when sheriff's deputies attempted to arrest [[IWW]] leader Richie "Blackie" Ford as he addressed striking field workers at the Durst Ranch. Four people died, including two workers, the local district attorney and a deputy. Despite the lack of evidence against them, Ford and another strike leader were found guilty of murder.<ref name="archive20140731042216">{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |title=Today in Labor History |author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute |location=Rochester, New York |accessdate=2015-09-16 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140731042216/http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |archivedate=July 31, 2014 }}</ref> |- |December 7, 1913 |Painesdale, MI | style="text-align: center;"|copper mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|3 |Dally-Jane murders: Part of the [[Copper Country strike of 1913–1914|Copper Country Strike of 1913-1914]]. Three striking miners (two Finnish brothers named Huhta and an Austrian) fired random rifle shots from 50 yards into the boarding house of Thomas Dally on Baltic Street, which housed replacement miners. The gunshots killed Dally and two English brothers, William Arthur Jane and Thomas Henry Jane. The attached house also received fire, injuring 13-year-old Mary Nicholson.<ref>{{cite web| title=The Dally-Jane Murders in Painesdale during the Copper Strike of 1913-14 (A personal account) | url= http://www.copperrange.org/strike.htm | first=Kevin |last=Musser|accessdate=2015-01-01}}</ref> |---- |December 24, 1913 |Red Jacket, MI | style="text-align: center;"|copper mining | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="11"|11 (plus 62 children) |[[Italian Hall disaster]]: As the [[Copper Country strike of 1913–1914]] dragged on into the cold of December, the hatred on both sides grew.<ref name=filipelli/><sup>p. 326</sup> [[Anna Klobuchar Clemenc]] and the Women's Auxiliary of the [[Western Federation of Miners]] organized a Christmas-Eve party for strikers and their families. The hall was packed with 400 to 500 people when someone shouted "fire". There was no fire, but 73 people, 62 of them children, were crushed to death trying to escape. |---- |August 1, 1917 |Butte, MT | style="text-align: center;"|copper mining | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[Industrial Workers of the World|IWW]] organizer [[Frank Little (unionist)|Frank Little]] was lynched by six masked men. 10,000 workers lined the route of his funeral procession. Years later writer [[Dashiell Hammett]] would recall his early days as a Pinkerton detective agency operative and recount how a mine company representative offered him $5,000 to kill Little.<ref name="archive20140731042216"/> |---- |September 30, 1919 |Elaine, AR | style="text-align: center;"|agriculture | style="text-align: center;"|organizing, race | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="100"|about 100 |African-American farmers met to establish the [[Progressive Farmers and Household Union of America]] to fight for better pay and higher cotton prices. They were shot at by a group of whites and returned the fire. News of the confrontation spread and the [[Elaine race riot]] ensued, leaving at least 100 blacks dead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |title=Today in Labor History |author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute |location=Rochester, New York |accessdate=2015-09-16 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131001172317/http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |archivedate=October 1, 2013 }}</ref> |---- |November 11, 1919 |Centralia, WA | style="text-align: center;"|lumber | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |[[Centralia Massacre (Washington)|Centralia Massacre]]: Two American Legion members in an Armistice Day parade were shot dead by IWW members firing rifles, after which the unarmed Legionaires attempted to force their way into the IWW hall. Two more were shot dead by members of the IWW, after which an IWW organizer named [[Wesley Everest]] was lynched by vigilantes. |---- |November 22, 1919 |Bogalusa, LA | style="text-align: center;"|lumber | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|4 |Gunmen hired by the Great Southern Lumber Company converged on the organizing office of the International Union of Timber Workers and without warning began to shoot. Lem Williams was shot down at the front door, and J.P. Bouchillon and Thomas Gaines were then killed as each appeared at the doorway. Stanley O'Rourke attempted to leave by the back door where he was shot while coming out with his hands above his head.<ref>{{cite book|first1=Horace Mann|last1=Bond|first2=Julia W.|last2=Bond|title=The Star Creek Papers| editor-first=Adam|editor-last=Fairclough|publisher=University of Georgia Press|year=1997|page=13|isbn=978-0820319049}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bloody Bogalusa, 1919: When Four White Unionists Died Defending Their Black Comrades|url=http://www.internationalist.org/bloodybogalusa19191202.html|work=The Internationalist|date=February 2012|accessdate=2015-09-16}}</ref> |---- |August 5, 1920 |Denver, CO | style="text-align: center;"|streetcar | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|7 |[[Denver streetcar strike of 1920]]: Seven workers were killed and 80 others wounded over two nights of violent riots triggered by a streetcar strike.<ref>{{cite book | last = Devine | first = Edward T. | title = The Denver tramway strike of 1920 : report of an investigation made under the auspices of the Denver Commission of Religious Forces | publisher = The Denver Commission of Religious Forces | location = New York | year = 1921 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=iCBYAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="January 1, 1922"|Jan-Feb, 1922 |Oklahoma City, OK and Fort Worth TX | style="text-align: center;"|meatpacking | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |Two black strikebreaking meat packers were lynched during the [[Amalgamated Meat Cutters]] strike of 1921-22: Jake Brooks in Oklahoma City on January 14, 1922,<ref>{{cite news|title=Sixth Man Pleads in Lynching Case|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/texas/san-antonio/san-antonio-express/1922/01-26/page-7?tag=jake+brooks+oklahoma+city+lynching|accessdate=27 March 2016|publisher=San Antonio Express|date=January 26, 1922}}</ref> and an unnamed injured black meatpacker, kidnapped by the [[Ku Klux Klan|Klan]] from a hospital and lynched in February.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Rick Halpern|first1=Roger Horowitz|title=Meatpackers: An Oral History of Black Packinghouse Workers and Their Struggle for Racial and Economic Equality|date=1999|publisher=NYU Press|page=101}}</ref> |---- |January 16, 1923 |Harrison, AR | style="text-align: center;"|railroad | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |The "Harrison Railroad Riot": striking railroad worker Ed C. Gregor was jailed for discharging a shotgun in the air to fend off a mob, then kidnapped from jail and lynched on a railroad bridge. Other fellow AFL members were taken from their homes and flogged. The Klan had allied with townspeople, under economic pressure from the strike, to combat the strikers and their campaign of railroad bridge arson.<ref>http://www.encyclopediaofarkansas.net/encyclopedia/entry-detail.aspx?entryID=3700</ref> |---- |September 14, 1929 |Gastonia, NC | style="text-align: center;"|textile | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Textile mill striker and songwriter Ella May Wiggins, 29, a mother of five, was killed when local vigilantes forced the pickup truck in which she was riding off the road and began shooting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |title=Today in Labor History |author=Union Communication Services, The Worker Institute |location=Rochester, New York |accessdate=2015-09-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010160852/http://www.unionist.com/today-in-labor-history-95 |archivedate=2014-10-10 |df= }}</ref> |---- |March 6, 1930 |Philadelphia, PA | style="text-align: center;"|garment | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |One man, Carl Mackley, was shot to death and three others were wounded seriously in a battle between employees of the H. C. Aberle hosiery mills and members of the hosiery workers' union and their sympathizers.<ref>{{cite news|title=HOSIERY WORKER SLAIN When Mill Employees, Members of Union, Engage in Battle.| work= The Cincinnati Enquirer|location=Cincinnati, Ohio|date= March 7, 1930|page=15|accessdate=2016-08-11|url= https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/103453042/}}</ref> |---- |February 24, 1931 |Stroudsburg, PA | style="text-align: center;"|textile | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Twenty-year-old striking hosiery mill worker Alberta Bachman was shot and killed, and two others wounded, by a former striker who had returned to work. The former striker shot into a car he believed was going to throw rocks at his house. Bachman was a member of the American Federation of Full-Fashioned Hosiery Workers, striking Mammoth Mills.<ref>{{cite news|title=Girl Striker Killed, Two Wounded|url=http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/wisconsin/madison/madison-wisconsin-state-journal/1931/02-24?|accessdate=25 March 2016|agency=Madison State Journal|date=24 February 1931|pages= 1, 4}}</ref> |---- |July 16, 1931 |Camp Hill, Alabama | style="text-align: center;"|cotton workers | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Eight hundred black workers associated with the newly founded Croppers and Farm Workers Union struck in July for cash wages and a nine-month school year for tenant children, among other demands.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Feldman|first1=Glenn|title=Politics, Society, and the Klan in Alabama, 1915-1949|date=24 September 1999|publisher=University of Alabama Press|pages=261–2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=giv2CAAAQBAJ&pg=PA261|accessdate=16 April 2017|isbn=9780817309848}}</ref> On the 15th a vigilante anti-union white lynch mob descended on SCU meetings, but were held off by strike leader Ralph Gray. The following day a gun battle between Gray and the local sheriff left both wounded. Later a white mob assassinated Gray in his bed, burned down his house, and deposited his body on the grounds of the [[Tallapoosa County, Alabama|county courthouse]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Preece|first1=Harold|title=Epic of the Black Belt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y1cEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA75|accessdate=16 April 2017|publisher=The Crisis|date=1 March 1936}}</ref> By one report four other black union members were lynched.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Law|first1=Michael Keef|title=Alabama Sharecroppers Union|url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/h-2477|website=Encyclopedia of Alabama|accessdate=16 April 2017}}</ref> Workers immediately reorganized as the [[Sharecroppers' Union|Share Croppers Union]].<ref name="ABC-CLIO"/> |---- |October 19, 1933 |Springfield, IL | style="text-align: center;"|coal | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |While on strike with [[Progressive Miners of America]] and in a protest march at the state capitol, Taylorville coal miner Melville Staples was shot once in the chest and died within 15 minutes.<ref>http://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/illinois/alton/alton-evening-telegraph/1933/10-19?tag=kentucky+edgewater+coal+1934+killed</ref> The shooter was later identified as a local United Mine Workers official. |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="December 22, 1933"|December 22, 1933 and March 15, 1934 |Hudson, MI | style="text-align: center;"|auto | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|2 |Two auto unionists were killed by the [[Black Legion (political movement)|Black Legion]]:<ref name=Ferguson/>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2016}} George Marchuk of the Auto Workers Union, and John Bielak of the Hudson Motor Local of the AFL, both Communist labor activists found shot to death three months apart.<ref>{{cite book|title=Du Pont Dynasty: Behind the Nylon Curtain|publisher=Open Road Media|year=2014|first=Gerard|last=Colby|isbn=9780818403521|chapter=9}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="April 1, 1934"|April 1934 |Lakeland, FL | style="text-align: center;"|citrus | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |Frank Norman, a citrus workers union organizer, was abducted by [[Ku Klux Klan|Klansmen]], and never seen or heard from again.<ref name= cdcrt/><sup>p. 9</sup> |---- |August 20, 1934 |Portland, Oregon | style="text-align: center;"|longshoremen | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|1 |James Connor, a 22-year-old college student and newlywed working as a replacement worker on his vacation, was shot and killed in an altercation with striking longshoremen.<ref>Oregon Encyclopedia, "West coast waterfront strike of 1934," written by Michael Monk, online at http://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/west_coast_waterfront_strike_of_1934/</ref> This was one of a string of violent incidents, including visiting Senator [[Robert F. Wagner]] coming under fire. A second replacement worker named R.A. Griffin was also wounded in the head. |---- |June 19, 1935 |Union, South Carolina | style="text-align: center;"|textiles | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;"|2 |During a [[Textile Workers Union of America|United Textile Workers of America]] strike against Monarch Mills, a lunchtime fight at the mill gate became a riot. Overseer A.L. Stutts was shot and killed by Constable W.B. Franklin, who was then shot and killed by a third man.<ref>"Slain Constable Buried at Union", Spartanburg Herald-Journal, June 22, 1935, page 1</ref> |---- |November 30, 1935 |Tampa, FL | style="text-align: center;"|cigar mfg. | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;"|1 |In the 1930s, the [[Ku Klux Klan]] harassed and intimidated union leaders. On November 30, 1935, Tampa police raided an organizational meeting of "Modern Democrats" in a private home without a warrant. Joseph A. Shoemaker and five other organizers were taken to a Tampa police station.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=e9ngAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA389&lpg=PA389&dq=%22Modern+Democrats%22+1935#v=onepage&q=%22Modern%20Democrats%22%201935&f=false|accessdate=2015-09-07|first=Robert P.|last=Ingalls|pages=13–27|via=Institutional Life: Family, Schools, Race, and Religion — American Cities – A Collection of Essays (Routledge), ed. Shumsky, Neil L. (2014)|title=The Tampa Flogging Case, Urban Vigilantism|work=Florida Historical Quarterly| isbn=9781135604738|date=2014-06-23}}</ref> Five policemen then turned three of them over to a mob of Klansmen. Shoemaker died nine days later after he was stripped, flogged with tire chains, clubbed on the head, burned with a hot poker in the genitals, covered in boiling tar and feathers and paralyzed on one side. The cigar industry moguls of Tampa had actively opposed Shoemaker, had close ties to the police and posted bail for the arrested policemen.<ref name=cdcrt/> "A thorough investigation revealed that the murder resulted from a collaboration between Tampa Chief of Police R. G. Tittsworth and (the) local Klan."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Fiery Cross: The Ku Klux Klan in America|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1998|first=Wyn Craig|last=Wade|isbn=9780195123579|page=261}}</ref> |---- |data-sort-type="date" data-sort-value="December 9, 1936"|December 9 and 14, 1936 |Galveston and Houston, TX | style="text-align: center;"|shipping | style="text-align: center;"|strike | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number"|2 |Two strikers were killed in the [[1936 Gulf Coast maritime workers' strike]]: Johnny Kane, who was shot on December 4 by a union official, and who died on December 15, and an Alaskan striker named Peter Banfield, a tanker seaman fatally stabbed in a fight in Galveston on December 9.<ref>{{cite news|title=Houston Strikers Retake Old Hall 1 Shot 3 Beaten|url=https://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/texas/san-antonio/san-antonio-express/1936/12-05?tag=johnny+kane+wilbur+dickey&rtserp=tags/johnny-kane-wilbur-dickey?psb=relavance|accessdate=25 April 2017|publisher=San Antonio Express|date=5 December 1936}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Rank and File Seamen Attend Banfield Rites|url=https://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/texas/galveston/galveston-daily-news/1936/12-16/page-4?tag=peter+banfield+galveston+strike&rtserp=tags/peter-banfield-galveston-strike?psb=relavance|accessdate=25 April 2017|publisher=Galveston Daily News|date=16 December 1936}}</ref> |---- |November 3, 1979 |Greensboro, NC | style="text-align: center;"|textile | style="text-align: center;"|organizing | style="text-align: center;" data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="5"|5 |Five labor organizers were killed at the [[Greensboro Massacre]], as workers were attempting to organize across racial lines at various textile mills in the area. A rally to protest recruitment at the mills by the Ku Klux Klan and Nazis turned violent, resulting in the deaths of the organizers. |---- |} :''*'' includes labor organizers

revision.comment: Added {{[[:Template:lead too short|lead too short]]}} tag to article ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | image = TechCrunch Disrupt Europe Berlin 2013 (10534251124).jpg | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = Marco Börries 2013 in Berlin | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|08|01}} | occupation = IT entrepreneur | known_for = [[Star Division]], [[StarOffice]] }}
'''Marco Börries''' (born 1 August 1968) is a German IT entrepreneur. He is best known as the founder of [[Star Division]], who developed [[StarOffice]], which later became [[OpenOffice.org]].
== Career ==
Inspired by a student exchange program to [[Silicon Valley]] while he attended the {{ill|Gymnasium Oedeme|de}}, Marco Börries founded [[Star Division]] as a garage company in Lüneburg at the age of 16. As its first product the company distributed [[StarWriter (word processor)|StarWriter]], a [[word processor]] application developed by friends,<ref name="Vermes_1999"/> as an alternative to [[Microsoft]]'s office package. StarWriter later became [[StarOffice]] (and thereby was the foundation to [[OpenOffice.org|OpenOffice]] and [[LibreOffice]]).
StarOffice was sold over 25 million times. On 5 August 1999 Börries sold Star Division to [[Sun Microsystems]], where Börries also subsequently briefly employed.<ref name="heise /><ref name="chip" />
In parallel to Star Division Börries also founded the Hamburg-based company Star Finanz as a [[joint venture]] with [[Deutscher Sparkassen- und Giroverband|Deutsche Sparkassen-Organisation]], a German savings bank.<ref name="Hofmann_2014"/> With [[StarMoney]] the company grew to become a significant provider of [[home banking]] software in the years following. In early 2001, Börries sold his shares in this company as well.<ref name="Behr_2001"/>
In August 2001, Börries founded [[VerdiSoft]] and served as its CEO. The company developed the [[Yahoo! Go]] technology to enable [[mobile phone]]s to have screen-optimized access to emails, photos, messages and other web content. VerdiSoft including its technology know-how was sold to [[Yahoo]] in February 2005, where Börries worked as an Executive Vice President in the ''Connected Life'' division until April 2009.<ref name="Kuri_2009"/>
Until 2008 Börries lived with his wife and three children in California,<ref name="Lemm_2005"/> but then moved to Hamburg and Berlin in Germany.
On 1 September 2009, Marco Börries launched his latest business idea, NumberFour AG, based in Berlin. The company developed an open software platform ([[Platform as a Service|PaaS]]) for the development, distribution and marketing of [[vertical solution]]s for [[small business]]es. After four years of development, Börries gathered 38 million USDs from financial investors in mid 2013.<ref name="Hofmann_2014"/> Renamed enfore AG, the company launched a platform for small business in March 2017 connecting online services, software and hardware ([[Point-of-sale|PoS]] terminals).<ref name="Hüsing_2017"/>
Other entrepreneurial activities that did not lead to market entries were Adhoc Mobile GmbH, founded in 2009, and Mag10 GmbH, founded in 2010. This was a company to develop a solution for tablet publishing, but was shelved at the end of 2011.<ref name="Treiß_2012"/>

'''Marián Kočner''' is a [[Slovaks|Slovak]] enterpreneur operating mostly in the spheres of risk investment, financial development and property business. His name appeared in so-called "mafia lists"<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://domov.sme.sk/c/6279067/marian-kocner-mafian-ktory-neexistuje.html|title=Marián Kočner. Mafián, ktorý neexistuje|last=Burčík|first=Matúš|date=28 February 2012|website=SME|language=Slovak|trans-title=Marián Kočner. Mafia man, who does not exist|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dennik.hnonline.sk/slovensko/199450-mafianske-zoznamy-menoslov-moznych-pachatelov|title=Mafiánske zoznamy -- menoslov možných páchateľov|last=Dömeová|first=Annamária|date=21 June 2005|work=Hospodárske Noviny|access-date=8 April 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=Slovak|trans-title=Mafia lists - names of possible perpetrators}}</ref> - a set of documents allegedly leaked from police in 2005 containing lists of persons suspected of involvement in organized crime and vehicles used by them, intended as an aid for police patrols. Kočner's business practices had been a prominent topic of articles by Ján Kuciak,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dennikn.sk/1040891/o-com-pisal-zavrazdeny-novinar-kuciak-vedel-patrat-vo-verejnych-databazach-polovica-z-jeho-poslednych-textov-je-o-kocnerovi/|title=O čom písal zavraždený novinár Kuciak: Pátral vo verejných databázach, polovica z jeho posledných textov je o Kočnerovi|last=Mikušovič|first=Dušan|date=26 February 2018|website=Denník N|language=Slovak|trans-title=What did murdered journalist Ján Kuciak write about: He researched public databases, half of his latest stories are about Kočner|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref> an [[investigative journalist]] from ''Aktuality.sk'' who was [[Murder of Ján Kuciak|murdered in February 2018]]. Couple of months prior to Kuciak's death, Kočner had allegedly threatened to "dig up dirt" on Kuciak by phone, saying "I will focus especially on you, your mother, your father, on your siblings.".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dennikn.sk/872431/kocner-predal-byt-v-bonaparte-a-zastrasoval-novinara-ktory-o-tom-napisal/|title=Kočner predal byt v Bonaparte a zastrašoval novinára, ktorý o tom napísal|last=Tódová|first=Monika|date=6 September 2018|website=Denník N|language=Slovak|trans-title=Kočner sold his apartment in Bonaparte and threatened the journalist who wrote about it|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref> Kuciak had filed a [[criminal complaint]] but a subsequent police investigation concluded that Kočner's alleged statements did not constitute a criminal offence.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dennikn.sk/1040750/investigativneho-reportera-aktualit-jana-kuciaka-a-jeho-partnerku-zavrazdili/|title=Investigatívneho reportéra Aktualít Jána Kuciaka a jeho partnerku zavraždili, vláda núka milión eur za odhalenie páchateľov|last=Tódová|first=Monika|date=26 February 2018|website=Denník N|language=Slovak|trans-title=Aktuality's investigative journalist Ján Kuciak and his partner were murdered, government offers million euros for tracking down perpetrators|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref> After Kuciak's murder, general prosecutor Jaromír Čižnár ordered the case to be reopened, however police again closed the case with conclusion that Kočner's statements do not constitute criminal offence. ''Aktuality.sk'' subsequently published transcript of the phone call between Kuciak and Kočner.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/579295/allforjan-prestanete-pisat-hrozil-novinarovi-kocner-kompletny-prepis-rozhovoru/|title=#AllForJan: Prestanete písať, hrozil novinárovi Kočner (kompletný prepis rozhovoru)|last=|first=|date=8 April 2018|work=Aktuality.sk|access-date=8 April 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=Slovak|trans-title=#AllForJan: "You'll never write again", Kočner threatened journalist (full transcript of the conversation)}}</ref> He is also connected to Alena Z. (suspect charged of ordering murder) via Alena Z.'s daughter as her godfather.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20926821/the-murder-of-jan-kuciak-was-ordered-by-a-woman-the-price-for-his-head-was-70000.html|title=The price of Ján Kuciak's head was €70,000|last=|first=|date=1 October 2018|work=Slovak Spectator|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en}}</ref>
== Gamatex and TV Markíza == Kočner first gained public notoriety for his attempt to take over [[Markíza|TV Markíza]] in 1998.
[[Markíza|TV Markíza]], one of the first private television channels in Slovakia, was founded by [[Pavol Rusko]] and Sylvia Volzová in partnership with [[Central European Media Enterprises|CME Media Enterprises B.V.]] in 1996. Initially the channel was not successful in acquiring broadcasting license, licensing board objected that Rusko did not disclose Volzová as co-owner.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.zivot.sk/clanok/14901/pribeh-jednej-televizie-toto-vsetko-si-preskakala-markiza|title=Príbeh jednej televízie: Toto všetko si preskákala Markíza|last=|first=|date=4 October 2013|website=www.zivot.sk|language=Slovak|trans-title=Story of a TV channel: This is what Markíza went through|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=8 April 2018}}</ref> Rusko had entered into an agreement with Espé štúdio, company owned by Siloš Pohanka to pay 3 million DEM in exchange for help in getting broadcasting license for [[Markíza]]. Eventually the cast of licensing board changed, Markíza had secured broadcasting license and launched on 31 August 1996. However Rusko declared agreement with Espé štúdio invalid, as he argued that Markíza acquired license without help of Siloš Pohanka.<ref name=":2" /> After unsuccessful attempts at getting money from Rusko, Pohanka sold his claim to Gamatex, company owned by Kočner. Kočner persuaded Volzová to acknowledge the claim and Kočner started court procedures to have the claim paid out.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://strategie.hnonline.sk/media/1049630-ako-rusko-a-volzova-spoluzakladali-markizu|title=Ako Pavol Rusko a Sylvia Volzová zakladali a predávali Markízu|last=Petronela|first=Ševčíková|date=23 October 2017|website=strategie.hnonline.sk|trans-title=How Pavol Rusko and Sylvia Volzová founded and sold Markíza|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=8 April 2018}}</ref>
In August 1998 Kočner appeared at Markíza offices with court order giving him control over the TV station. When negotiations with Rusko regarding ownership dispute failed, Kočner occupied the TV station with hired private security and fired TV channel's top managers.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.sme.sk/c/2165289/televizia-markiza-obsadena.html|title=Televízia Markíza obsadená|last=Tóth|first=Peter|date=16 September 1998|work=SME|access-date=8 April 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=Slovak|trans-title=TV Markíza occupied}}</ref> This caused public outrage, as the takeover took place only 10 days before parliamentary elections. At that time TV Markíza was deemed the main news outlet opposing the government of [[Vladimír Mečiar]] and an attempt at takeover was considered an attack on press freedom. Several thousand<ref name=":3" /> of angry citizens gathered in front of Markíza's offices as a show of support and several politicians from opposition parties gave speeches at the rally. After two days, Kočner and his associates left the building<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sme.sk/c/2165498/gamatex-s-ochrankou-opustil-markizu-zamestnanci-dostali-zaruky-do-11-oktobra.html|title=Gamatex s ochrankou opustil Markízu, zamestnanci dostali záruky do 11. októbra|last=|first=|date=18 September 1998|work=SME|access-date=8 April 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=Slovak|trans-title=Gamatex and private security have left Markíza, employees got guarantees until 11th October}}</ref> and ownership dispute continued in courts. According to news reports,<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dennik.hnonline.sk/153247-rusko-v-markize-skoncil-televiziu-ovladli-americania|title=Rusko v Markíze skončil, televíziu ovládli Američania|last=Tettinger|first=Marek|date=2 November 2005|work=Hospodárske Noviny|access-date=8 April 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=Slovak|trans-title=Rusko is done with Markíza, channel taken over by Americans}}</ref> Kočner's involvement in TV Markíza seemingly ended in 2000 when Rusko bought Gamatex through intermediaries.
In a 2006 interview with ''aktualne.sk'' (not to be confused with ''aktuality.sk'') Kočner said the security firm involved in takeover of Markíza belonged to Peter Čongrády, a local mafia boss, however in later interviews he denied hiring Čongrády.<ref name=":0" />
In June 2016 Kočner's company "Správa a inkaso zmeniek" initiated court proceedings with [[Pavol Rusko]] and [[Markíza|TV Markíza]] to collect money owed to him under four promissory notes amounting to approx. €69 million. Kočner claimed that Rusko issued those promissory notes in June 2000 with Markíza providing endorsement for the notes. At that time Rusko was the executive director of TV Markíza as well as one of its shareholders<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/925645/000092564517000003/cetv-1231201610k.htm#sDD7836481E5EC03FE544BC286EF01E82|title=CME Enterprises Ltd. annual report|last=|first=|date=|website=US Securities and Exchange Commission website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. Two of those notes amounted to €8.3 million each with maturity date in 2015 and another two were signed as "blank cheque" with amount €26 million and maturity date in 2016 added later<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://ekonomika.sme.sk/c/20813208/markiza-prehrala-kocnerovi-ma-platit-miliony-za-cudne-zmenky.html|title=Markíza prehrala, Kočnerovi má platiť milióny za čudné zmenky|last=|first=|date=26 April 2018|work=SME|access-date=3 November 2018|language=Slovak|trans-title=Markíza lost, must pay Kočner millions due to peculiar notes}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.etrend.sk/ekonomika/kocner-zaluje-markizu-ziada-miliony-za-ruskove-zmenky.html|title=Kočner žaluje Markízu. Žiada milióny za Ruskove zmenky|last=Petková|first=Zuzana|date=3 May 2017|work=TREND|access-date=3 November 2018|language=Slovak|trans-title=Kočner sues Markíza, demands millions for Rusko notes}}</ref>. Rusko acknowledged Kočner's claim in court and declared that the promissory notes were intended to resolve ownership dispute with Gamatex<ref name=":5" />. Markíza's management was unaware of the existence of the promissory notes<ref name=":4" />. They were not recorded in either company's accounting and were not discovered during the preparation of due diligence report when [[Central European Media Enterprises|CME]] became only shareholder of TV Markíza<ref name=":6" />. In April 2018 court declared Kočner's claim as valid<ref name=":5" />, however in retaliation TV Markíza filed a criminal complaint against Kočner and Rusko for forging the promissory notes<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.omediach.com/tv/13214-markiza-podala-trestne-oznamenie-na-ruska-a-kocnera|title=Markíza podala trestné oznámenie na Ruska a Kočnera|last=Kernová|first=Miroslava|date=14 May 2018|website=oMediach.com|language=Slovak|trans-title=Markíza filed criminal complaint against Rusko and Kočner|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 November 2018}}</ref>. In addition, investigation into possible tax evasion began, since by not disclosing the possession of the promissory notes to tax authority Kočner's companies avoided paying tax from interest on the notes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.etrend.sk/ekonomika/podnikanie-kocnera-nehnutelnosti-dph-a-zmenky-aj-od-penty.html|title=Kočner a zmenky: má ich veľa. Aj od Penty|last=Petková|first=Zuzana|date=21 June 2018|work=TREND|access-date=3 November 2018|language=Slovak|trans-title=Kočner and IOUs: He's got many, from Penta as well}}</ref>
In June 2018, Kočner has been detained by Slovak authorities in the case of promissory notes forgery together with Pavol Rusko, as well as various tax-related crimes. He remains in custody as of October 2018, although no criminal charges have yet been raised.<ref>{{cite web |title=NAKA detains businessman Kočner |url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20854251/naka-detains-businessman-kocner.html |website=The Slovak Spectator |publisher=Petit Press |accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kočner, Marián}} [[Category:Slovak businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]]

The '''modified internal rate of return''' ('''MIRR''') is a [[finance|financial]] measure of an [[investment]]'s attractiveness.<ref>Lin, S. A. Y., "The modified internal rate of return and investment criterion," ''The Engineering Economist'' 21(4), 1976, 237-247.</ref><ref>Beaves, R. G., "Net present value and the rate of return: Implicit and explicit reinvestment assumptions," ''The Engineering Economist'' 33, 1988, 275-302.</ref> It is used in [[capital budgeting]] to rank alternative investments of equal size. As the name implies, MIRR is a modification of the [[internal rate of return]] (IRR) and as such aims to resolve some problems with the IRR.
==Problems with the IRR== While there are several [[Internal rate of return#Problems with using internal rate of return|problems with the IRR]], MIRR resolves two of them.
Firstly, IRR is sometimes misapplied, under an assumption that interim positive cash flows are reinvested at the same rate of return as that of the project that generated them.<ref>[http://www.cfo.com/article.cfm/3304945 Internal Rate of Return: A Cautionary Tale]</ref> This is usually an unrealistic scenario and a more likely situation is that the funds will be reinvested at a rate closer to the firm's cost of capital. The IRR therefore often gives an unduly optimistic picture of the projects under study. Generally for comparing projects more fairly, the [[weighted average cost of capital]] should be used for reinvesting the interim cash flows.
Secondly, more than one IRR can be found for projects with alternating positive and negative cash flows, which leads to confusion and ambiguity. MIRR finds only one value.
==Calculation of the MIRR== MIRR is calculated as follows:
<math>\mbox{MIRR}=\sqrt[n]{\frac{FV(\text{positive cash flows, reinvestment rate})}{-PV(\text{negative cash flows, finance rate})}}-1</math>,
where ''n'' is the number of equal periods at the end of which the cash flows occur (not the number of cash flows), ''PV'' is [[present value]] (at the beginning of the first period), ''FV'' is [[future value]] (at the end of the last period).
The formula adds up the negative cash flows after discounting them to time zero using the external cost of capital, adds up the positive cash flows including the proceeds of reinvestment at the external reinvestment rate to the final period, and then works out what rate of return would cause the magnitude of the discounted negative cash flows at time zero to be equivalent to the future value of the positive cash flows at the final time period.
[[Spreadsheet|Spreadsheet applications]], such as [[Microsoft Excel]], have inbuilt functions to calculate the MIRR. In Microsoft Excel this function is "=MIRR(...)".
===Example=== If an investment project is described by the sequence of cash flows:
{| class="wikitable" align="left" |- ! Year ! Cash flow |- align="center" | 0 | -1000 |- align="center" | 1 | -4000 |- align="center" | 2 | 5000 |- align="center" | 3 | 2000 |} {{-}}
then the IRR <math>r</math> is given by
<math>\mbox{NPV} = -1000 + \frac{-4000}{(1+r)^1} + \frac{5000}{(1+r)^2} + \frac{2000}{(1+r)^3} = 0</math>.
In this case, the answer is 25.48% (with this conventional pattern of cash flows, the project has a unique IRR).
To calculate the MIRR, we will assume a finance rate of 10% and a reinvestment rate of 12%. First, we calculate the present value of the negative cash flows (discounted at the finance rate):
<math>PV(\text{negative cash flows, finance rate}) = -1000 + \frac{-4000}{(1+10\%)^1} = -4636.36</math>.
Second, we calculate the future value of the positive cash flows (reinvested at the reinvestment rate):
<math>FV(\text{positive cash flows, reinvestment rate}) = 5000\cdot(1+12\%)^1 + 2000 = 7600</math>.
Third, we find the MIRR:
<math>\mbox{MIRR}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{7600}{4636.36}}-1=17.91\%</math>.
The calculated MIRR (17.91%) is significantly different from the IRR (25.48%).
==Comparing projects of different sizes== Like the internal rate of return, the modified internal rate of return is not valid for ranking projects of different sizes, because a larger project with a smaller modified internal rate of return may have a higher net present value. However, there exist variants of the modified internal rate of return which can be used for such comparisons.<ref>Shull, D. M., "Efficient capital project selection through a yield-based capital budgeting technique," ''The Engineering Economist'' 38(1), 1992, 1-18.</ref><ref>Hajdasinski, M., "Remarks in the context of 'The case for the generalized net present value formula'," ''The Engineering Economist'' 40(2), 1995, 201-210.</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Mathematical finance]] [[Category:Investment]] [[Category:Capital budgeting]]

{{other uses}} {{distinguish|Civil service}} {{refimprove|date=September 2016}}
[[File:La piscine regtangulaire Hammam essalhine khenchela aures.jpg|thumb|right|[[Thermae|Roman public bath]], still [[Hammam Essalihine|in use]]]] '''Public service'''<ref name="McGregor1982">{{cite journal |url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/197199863 |title=Symposium: The Public Service as Institution |journal=Public Administration Review |location=Washington |first1=Eugene B. |last1=McGregor Jr. |first2=Alan K. |last2=Campbell |first3=John W. |last3=Macy |first4=Harlan |last4=Cleveland |volume=42 |issue=4 |page=304-320 |date=July-August 1982 |jstor=i240003}}</ref> is a [[Service (economics)|service]] which is provided by [[government]] to people living within its jurisdiction, either directly (through the [[public sector]]) or by financing provision of services. The term is associated with a social consensus (usually expressed through [[democratic election]]s) that certain services should be available to all, regardless of [[income]], [[physical ability]] or [[intelligence|mental acuity]]. Even where public services are neither publicly provided nor publicly financed, for social and political reasons they are usually subject to [[regulation]] going beyond that applying to most [[economic sectors]]. [[Public policy]]<ref name="Anderfuhren2014">{{cite journal |url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1639861884 |title=Policy Environment and Public Service Motivation |journal=Public Administration |location=London |first1=Simon |last1=Anderfuhren-Biget |first2=Frédéric |last2=Varone |first3=David |last3=Giauque |volume=92 |issue=4 |pages=807-825 |date=December 2014 |doi=10.1111/padm.12026}}</ref> when made in the public's interest and motivations can provide public services. Public service is also a course that can be studied at a college or university. Examples of public services are the [[fire brigade]], [[police]], [[air force]], and [[paramedics]].
==Sectors== Public services may be associated with fundamental [[human rights]] (such as the right to water). The Volunteer Fire Dept. and Ambulance Corps. are institutions with the mission of servicing the community. A service is helping others with a specific need or want. Here, service ranges from a doctor curing an illness, to a repair person, to a food pantry.
In modern [[developed countries]], the term "public services" (or "services of general interest") often includes:{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}} * [[Court|Courts]] * [[Electricity]] * [[Education]], [e.g. state (public) schools, public universities, etc...] * [[Emergency service]]s, (e.g. Fire, EMS, Law Enforcement, Search and Rescue, etc...) * [[Environmental protection]] * [[Health care]] * [[Military]] * [[Public transportation]] * [[Public buildings]] * [[Social services]], (e.g. public housing, social welfare, food subsidies, etc...) * [[Telecommunications]] * [[Urban planning]] * [[Transportation infrastructure]] * [[Waste management]], (e.g. wastewater, solid waste, recycling, etc...) * [[Water supply network]]
==Public administration== {{Main article|Public Administration}}In modern democracies, public service is often performed by [[Employment|employees]] known as [[Civil service|civil servants]] who are hired by elected [[officials]]. Government agencies are not profit-oriented and their employees are motivated very differently.<ref name=":0" /> Studies of their work have found contrasting results including both higher levels of effort<ref name=":0">{{cite journal |title=Government Employees: Working Hard or Hardly Working? |journal=The American Review of Public Administration |first1=Sue A. |last1=Frank |first2=Gregory B. |last2=Lewis |volume=34 |issue=1 |pages=36-51 |date=March 2004 |doi=10.1177/0275074003258823}}</ref> and fewer hours of work.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.heritage.org/jobs-and-labor/report/government-employees-work-less-private-sector-employees |title=Government Employees Work Less than Private-Sector Employees |journal=Backgrounder |publisher=The Heritage Foundation |first=Jason |last=Richwine |issue=2724 |pages=1-6 |date=11 September 2012 |access-date=16 January 2016}}</ref> A survey in the UK found that private sector hiring managers do not credit government experience as much as private sector experience.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://business.financialpost.com/executive/careers/public-sector-stigma |title=Public sector stigma: The 100,000 workers Tim Hudak removes from the provincial payroll could have a tough transition to the private sector |work=Financial Post |first=Dan |last=Ovsey |date=27 May 2014 |access-date=16 January 2016}}</ref> Public workers tend to make less in wages when adjusting for education, although that difference is reduced when benefits and hours are included.<ref name=":1">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/02/07/are-public-sector-employees-overpaid/ |title=Are public-sector employees “overpaid”? |work=The Washington Post |first=Sasha |last=Volokh |date=7 February 2014 |accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> Public workers have other intangible benefits such as increased job security.<ref name=":1" />
==Characteristics== A public service may sometimes have the characteristics of a [[public good]] (being [[non-rivalrous]] and [[non-excludable]]), but most are services which may (according to prevailing [[social norms]]) be under-provided by the [[Market (economics)|market]]. In most cases public services are [[Service (economics)|services]], i.e. they do not involve manufacturing of [[good (accounting)|goods]]. They may be provided by local or national monopolies, especially in sectors which are [[natural monopoly|natural monopolies]].
They may involve outputs that are hard to attribute to specific individual effort or hard to measure in terms of key characteristics such as quality. They often require high levels of training and education. They may attract people with a public service ethos who wish to give something to the wider public or community through their work.
==History==
Governing bodies have long provided core public services. The tradition of keeping citizens secure through organized military defence dates to at least four thousand years ago.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J53rAgAAQBAJ |title=The Power of the Bull |publisher=Routledge |location=London |last1=Rice |first1=Michael |page=13 |date=1998 |isbn=978-1-317-72583-1 |quote=As the more advanced social institutions began to take shape they contributed to some counterbalancing of the essential insecurity of man's condition. It was inevitable that ambitious and assertive men should see an opportunity for establishing for themselves positions of power and influence. No doubt many such occasions had their origins in a genuine concern for the public good [...] The position of [...] the war-band leader as the strong arm of the community's defence would increasingly be confirmed by the subjection of the community to the members of what [...] were becoming, demonstrably, elites, [...] This period, embracing part of the fifth and all of the fourth and third millennia before the present era, is absolutely pivotal to the development of the modern world.}}</ref>
Maintaining order through local delegated authority originated at least as early as the [[Warring States period]] (5th to 3rd centuries BCE) in ancient China with the institution of ''xian'' (prefectures) under the control of a centrally-appointed prefect. Historical evidence of state provision of [[dispute resolution]] through a legal/justice system goes back at least as far as ancient Egypt.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j3pmDAAAQBAJ |title=Law's Political Foundations: Rivers, Rifles, Rice, and Religion |publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing |location=Cheltemham, Gloucestershire |last1=Haley |first1=John O. |pages=43-44 |date=2016 |isbn=978-1-78536-850-9 |quote=Pharaonic Egypt epitomizes a regulatory, public law regime. [...] The principal function of this elaborate apparatus was to maintain order and security, and, above all, to acquire as much of the surplus agricultural wealth and labor as possible.}}</ref>
A primary public service in ancient history involved ensuring the general favor of the [[gods]] through a theologically and ceremonially correct [[state religion]].<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JcvZCgAAQBAJ |title=The Cambridge Companion to Political Theology |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=New York |last1=Hovey |first1=Craig |last2=Phillips |first2=Elizabeth |page=4-5 |date=2015 |isbn=978-1-107-05274-1 |quote=To ensure the favor of the gods was the preeminent task of ancient rulers worldwide, for they all were priestly kings. The Roman Caesar was the ''pontifex maximus'' of Rome's state god. The Chinese emperor certainly stood over his subjects as 'Son of Heaven,' but if he fell into disfavor with heaven and his country was visited by famine, plague, earthquakes, and floods, he could be overthrown. The Moloch of Carthage demanded children as sacrifices; the Aztecs and Mayas offered their Gods still-quivering hearts. These political religions were ''do ut des'' religions in which the relationship between deity and worshippers was one of contractual exchange.}}</ref>
The widespread provision of [[public utility|public utilities]] as public services in developed countries usually began in the late nineteenth century, often with the [[municipal]] development of [[gas]] and [[water]] services. Later, governments began to provide other services such as [[electricity]] and [[healthcare]]. In most developed countries local or national governments continue to provide such services, the biggest exceptions being the [[United States|U.S.]] and the [[United Kingdom|UK]], where private provision is arguably proportionally more significant.{{citation needed|reason=Compare: National Health Service in the UK|date=March 2015}} Nonetheless, such privately provided public services are often strongly regulated, for example (in the US) by [[Public Utility Commission]]s.
In [[developing countries]] public services tend to be much less well developed. For example, water services might only be available to the [[wealthy]] [[middle class]]. For [[political]] reasons the service is often [[subsidized]], which reduces the finance potentially available for expansion to [[Poverty|poorer]] communities.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
==Nationalization== {{main|Nationalization}} Nationalization took off following the [[World War]]s of the first half of the twentieth century. Across [[Europe]], because of the extreme demands on industries and the economy, [[central planning]] was required to make production maximally efficient. Many public services, especially electricity, gas and public transport are products of this era. Following the Second World War, many countries also began to implement [[universal health care]] and expanded [[education]] under the funding and guidance of the state.
==Privatization== [[File:A group of Damas de Rojo.jpg|thumb|A group of [[Chile]]an 'Damas de Rojo', volunteers on their local hospital.]] {{main|Privatization}} There are several ways to privatize public services. A free-market corporation may be established and sold to private investors, relinquishing government control altogether. Thus it becomes a private (not public) service. Another option, used in the [[Nordic countries]], is to establish a corporation, but keep ownership or voting power essentially in the hands of the government. For example, the [[Finland|Finnish state]] owned 49% of [[Kemira]] until 2007, the rest being owned by private investors. A 49% share did not make it a "government enterprise", but it meant that all other investors together would have to oppose the state's opinion in order to overturn the state's decisions in the shareholder's meeting. Regulated corporation can also acquire permits on the agreement that they fulfill certain public service duties. When a private corporation runs a [[natural monopoly]], then the corporation is typically heavily regulated, to prevent abuse of monopoly power. Lastly, the government can buy the service on the free market. In many countries, [[medication]] is provided in this manner: the government reimburses part of the price of the medication. Also, bus traffic, electricity, healthcare and waste management are privatized in this way. One recent innovation, used in the UK increasingly as well as Australia and Canada is [[public-private partnership]]s. This involves giving a long lease to private consortia in return for partly funding infrastructure.
==See also== {{Too many see alsos|date=April 2017}} * [[EPSU]] European Public Services Unions * [[CEEP]] European Centre of Enterprises with Public Participation and of Enterprises of General Economic Interest * [[Certificate of public convenience and necessity]] * [[Good governance]] * [[Infrastructure]] * [[Right to Public Services legislation]] * [[New Public Management]] * [[United Nations Public Service Awards]] * [[UN Public Service Day]] * [[VÖWG]] Austrian Association for Public and Social Economy
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{no footnotes|section|date=December 2016}} * [http://www.municipalservicesproject.org Municipal Services Project] * [http://www.world-psi.org Public Services International] * [http://www.psiru.org Public Services International Research Unit] * Daniel Chavez (ed), [http://www.tni.org/detail_pub.phtml?know_id=96 Beyond the Market: The Future of Public Services], TNI Public Services Yearbook 2005/6, [[Transnational Institute]] / Public Services International Research Unit (PSIRU), February 2006 * [http://ceep.eu European Centre of Enterprises with Public Participation and of Enterprises of General Economic Interest]
{{Public services|state=expanded}} {{Civil service|state|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2014}} [[File:Erddig Mortar making machine - geograph.org.uk - 351058.jpg|thumb|An old fashioned type of pug mill in Wales. Attribution: Betty Longbottom, geograph.org.uk - 351058]] A '''pugmill''' or '''pug mill''' is a machine in which clay or other materials are mixed into a plastic state or a similar machine for the [[trituration]] of ore.<ref>"Pug-mill" def. 1. ''Oxford English Dictionary'' Second Edition on CD-ROM (v. 4.0) © Oxford University Press 2009 </ref> Industrial applications are found in [[pottery]], [[brick]]s, [[cement]] and some parts of the [[concrete]] and [[asphalt]] mixing processes. A pugmill may be a fast continuous mixer. A continuous pugmill can achieve a thoroughly mixed, homogeneous mixture in a few seconds, and the right machines can be matched to the right application by taking into account the factors of agitation, drive assembly, inlet, discharge, cost and maintenance.<ref>http://www.bulk-solids-handling.com/?q=topics/processing/mixing-blending/pugmill-mixer-selection-guide {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003101542/http://www.bulk-solids-handling.com/?q=topics%2Fprocessing%2Fmixing-blending%2Fpugmill-mixer-selection-guide |date=2015-10-03 }}</ref> Mixing materials at optimum moisture content requires the forced mixing action of the pugmill paddles, while soupy materials might be mixed in a drum mixer. A typical pugmill consists of a horizontal boxlike chamber with a top inlet and a bottom discharge at the other end, 2 shafts with opposing paddles, and a drive assembly. Some of the factors affecting mixing and residence time are the number and the size of the paddles, paddle swing arc, overlap of left and right swing arc, size of mixing chamber, length of pugmill floor, and material being mixed.
==Common construction and industrial uses==
Road Base - Dense well-graded aggregate, uniformly mixed, wetted, and densely compacted for building the foundation under a pavement.
Lime Addition to asphalt – Lime may be added to the cold feed of an [[asphalt plant]] to strengthen the binding properties of the asphalt.
Flyash Conditioning – Wetting [[fly ash]] in a pugmill to stabilize the ash so that it won’t create dust. Some flyashes have cementitious properties when wetted and can be used to stabilize other materials.
Waste stabilization – various waste streams are remediated with pugmills forcing the mixing of the wastes with remediation agents.
[[Roller-compacted concrete]] – (RCC) or rolled concrete is a special blend of concrete that has the same ingredients as conventional concrete but in different ratios. It has cement, water, and aggregates, but RCC is much drier and essentially has no slump. RCC is placed in a manner similar to paving, often by dump trucks or conveyors, spread by bulldozers or special modified asphalt pavers. After placement it is compacted by vibratory rollers. The “stiff” nature of RCC may require a paddle type pugmill to force the materials to mix completely and discharge easily.
[[Ceramic]]s pug mills, or commonly just "pugs", are not used to grind or mix, rather they extrude clay bodies prior to shaping processes. Some can be fitted with a vacuum system that ensures the extruded clay bodies have no entrapped air. According to the 1913 edition of [[Webster's Dictionary]], a clay pug mill typically consists of an upright shaft armed with projecting knives, which is caused to revolve in a hollow cylinder, tub, or vat, in which the clay body is placed.
Pugmills that run intermittently are used in the [[kaolin]] mining industry to mix certain grades of [[kaolin]] clay with water.
==See also== * [[Concrete slump test]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{Commons category|Pug mills}}
*[http://www.tpub.com/content/engine/14080/css/14080_178.htm Pugmill mixing explanation] *[http://www.thepotteries.org/jobs/pug_mill.htm Pug Mill page at potteries.org] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20151003101542/http://www.bulk-solids-handling.com/?q=topics%2Fprocessing%2Fmixing-blending%2Fpugmill-mixer-selection-guide Pugmill Mixer Selection Guide]
